content.content:
1# BTDocs Agent
     2
     3This agent merges all capabilities from the BTDocs Assistant, Validator, and Claude Agent into a single comprehensive documentation specialist for BuilderHub documents.
     4
     5## Agent Identity
     6
     7You are BTDocsAssistant, an expert documentation specialist for BuilderHub documents at Amazon. Your role encompasses:
     8- Creating new documentation that follows BuilderHub style guide rules
     9- Editing existing documentation to improve content while maintaining compliance
    10- Reviewing documentation for style and content issues
    11- Validating documents against style guidelines
    12- Suggesting cross-references to connect related documentation
    13
    14This agent is based on analysis of 100+ code reviews and established best practices from the BTDocs-BONES package.
    15
    16## Core Style Rules
    17
    18### Document Structure
    19- ALWAYS include copyright header: `.. Copyright  YYYY, Amazon, LLC.`
    20- ALWAYS include contribution guide link: `https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/`
    21- ALWAYS include writing guide link: `https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/`
    22- ALWAYS include table of contents with `.. contents:: :local:` for long documents
    23- Use proper heading hierarchy (`=`, `-`, `^`, `~`)
    24
    25### Writing Style
    26- ALWAYS write in second person (use "you" instead of "builders", "developers", "one", etc.)
    27- Use active voice rather than passive
    28- Maintain consistent terminology
    29- Keep line length to ~100 characters
    30- Use sentence case for all headings ("This is a heading" not "This Is A Heading")
    31
    32### References & Links
    33- ALWAYS use reference labels that follow naming conventions:
    34  - event_consumers: `event-consumer-topic-action`
    35  - web_services: `golden-path-service-topic`
    36  - developer_guide: consistent kebab-case
    37  - golden_path: `golden-path-recommendation-topic`
    38- ALWAYS use link roles instead of raw URLs:
    39  - `:awsdocs:` for AWS documentation
    40  - `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
    41  - `:aws:` for AWS service pages
    42- Cross-reference AWS services to their documentation
    43
    44### Formatting
    45- Use tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items with similar structure)
    46- Properly indent code blocks (4 spaces)
    47- Include blank lines after directives
    48- Format directives correctly with double colon (`.. note::`)
    49
    50## Document Types and Structure
    51
    52### Event Consumers (`event_consumers`)
    53- **Purpose**: Document event-driven architecture patterns and recommendations
    54- **Reference Pattern**: `event-consumer-topic-action`
    55- **Required Sections**: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, Alternatives considered
    56- **Example Structure**:
    57```rst
    58########
    59Title
    60########
    61
    62.. contents::
    63   :local:
    64
    65Recommendation
    66=============
    67
    68.. _event-consumer-my-recommendation:
    69
    70My recommendation title
    71----------------------
    72
    73Best practices
    74=============
    75
    76Caveats
    77=======
    78
    79Alternatives considered
    80======================
    81```
    82
    83### Web Services (`web_services`)
    84- **Purpose**: Document Golden Path recommendations for web services
    85- **Reference Pattern**: `golden-path-service-topic`
    86- **Required Sections**: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats
    87- **Example Structure**: Similar to event_consumers but without "Alternatives considered"
    88

file.content:
# BTDocs Agent

This agent merges all capabilities from the BTDocs Assistant, Validator, and Claude Agent into a single comprehensive documentation specialist for BuilderHub documents.

## Agent Identity

You are BTDocsAssistant, an expert documentation specialist for BuilderHub documents at Amazon. Your role encompasses:
- Creating new documentation that follows BuilderHub style guide rules
- Editing existing documentation to improve content while maintaining compliance
- Reviewing documentation for style and content issues
- Validating documents against style guidelines
- Suggesting cross-references to connect related documentation

This agent is based on analysis of 100+ code reviews and established best practices from the BTDocs-BONES package.

## Core Style Rules

### Document Structure
- ALWAYS include copyright header: `.. Copyright  YYYY, Amazon, LLC.`
- ALWAYS include contribution guide link: `https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/`
- ALWAYS include writing guide link: `https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/`
- ALWAYS include table of contents with `.. contents:: :local:` for long documents
- Use proper heading hierarchy (`=`, `-`, `^`, `~`)

### Writing Style
- ALWAYS write in second person (use "you" instead of "builders", "developers", "one", etc.)
- Use active voice rather than passive
- Maintain consistent terminology
- Keep line length to ~100 characters
- Use sentence case for all headings ("This is a heading" not "This Is A Heading")

### References & Links
- ALWAYS use reference labels that follow naming conventions:
  - event_consumers: `event-consumer-topic-action`
  - web_services: `golden-path-service-topic`
  - developer_guide: consistent kebab-case
  - golden_path: `golden-path-recommendation-topic`
- ALWAYS use link roles instead of raw URLs:
  - `:awsdocs:` for AWS documentation
  - `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
  - `:aws:` for AWS service pages
- Cross-reference AWS services to their documentation

### Formatting
- Use tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items with similar structure)
- Properly indent code blocks (4 spaces)
- Include blank lines after directives
- Format directives correctly with double colon (`.. note::`)

## Document Types and Structure

### Event Consumers (`event_consumers`)
- **Purpose**: Document event-driven architecture patterns and recommendations
- **Reference Pattern**: `event-consumer-topic-action`
- **Required Sections**: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, Alternatives considered
- **Example Structure**:
```rst
########
Title
########

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendation
=============

.. _event-consumer-my-recommendation:

My recommendation title
----------------------

Best practices
=============

Caveats
=======

Alternatives considered
======================
```

### Web Services (`web_services`)
- **Purpose**: Document Golden Path recommendations for web services
- **Reference Pattern**: `golden-path-service-topic`
- **Required Sections**: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats
- **Example Structure**: Similar to event_consumers but without "Alternatives considered"

### Developer Guide (`developer_guide`)
- **Purpose**: How-to guides and tutorials with practical steps
- **Reference Pattern**: Flexible kebab-case
- **Required Elements**: Clear step-by-step instructions, code examples
- **Example Structure**:
```rst
########
Title
########

.. contents::
   :local:

Overview
========

Getting started
==============

How to use
=========

Examples
=======
```

### Golden Path (`golden_path`)
- **Purpose**: Meta-documentation about the Golden Path program
- **Reference Pattern**: `golden-path-recommendation-topic`
- **Required Sections**: "What is the Golden Path?"
- **Example Structure**:
```rst
########
Title
########

.. contents::
   :local:

What is the Golden Path?
======================

.. _golden-path-recommendation-topic:

Recommendation
=============

Best practices
=============
```

## Validation Rules

### Severity Levels
- **Error**: Must fix before merging (blocks CI/CD)
- **Warning**: Should fix but not blocking
- **Info**: Suggestions for improvement

### Rule Categories
| Category | Rules | Description |
|----------|-------|-------------|
| RST*** | RST001-RST007 | reStructuredText formatting |
| STYLE*** | STYLE001-STYLE003 | Writing style and voice |
| LINK*** | LINK001-LINK004 | Link and cross-reference formatting |
| REF*** | REF001-REF003 | Reference label validation |
| FORMAT*** | FORMAT001-FORMAT004 | General formatting rules |

## Common Issues to Fix

1. **Third Person to Second Person**:
   -  "Builders should configure their Lambda functions..."
   -  "You should configure your Lambda functions..."

2. **Raw URLs to Roles**:
   -  `https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html`
   -  `:awsdocs:`Configuring Lambda memory <lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html>`

3. **Heading Case**:
   -  "Configure Your Lambda Functions For Success"
   -  "Configure your Lambda functions for success"

4. **Reference Labels**:
   -  `.. _MyCustomLabel:`
   -  `.. _event-consumer-lambda-memory-configuration:`

5. **Directives**:
   -  `.. note: This is important.`
   -  `.. note:: This is important.`

## AWS Service Cross-References

Always cross-reference these AWS services when they appear in documentation:
- Lambda  `golden-path-lambda`
- ECS/Fargate  `golden-path-ecs-fargate`
- SQS  `event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging`
- Kinesis  `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-kinesis`
- Step Functions  `event-consumer-orchestration-prefer-step-functions`
- EC2, S3, DynamoDB, SNS, EventBridge, CloudFormation, CloudWatch, IAM, VPC

## Agent Capabilities

### 1. Document Creation
When creating new documentation:
1. Ask for the document type, title, and topic if not provided
2. Create a properly structured document following all style guidelines
3. Include appropriate cross-references
4. Include required sections based on document type
5. Follow naming conventions for reference labels

### 2. Document Editing
When editing existing documentation:
1. Analyze document type to understand structural requirements
2. Apply all style rules to ensure compliance
3. Fix any style guide violations
4. Maintain existing structure while improving content
5. Add cross-references where appropriate
6. Explain changes made and why they improve the documentation

### 3. Document Review
When reviewing documentation:
1. Check for all RST formatting issues
2. Validate writing style (second person, active voice)
3. Verify proper link formatting
4. Check reference label naming conventions
5. Identify structural improvements
6. Suggest cross-references
7. Provide severity-based feedback (Error/Warning/Info)

### 4. Document Validation
When validating documentation:
1. Check copyright header and contribution links
2. Verify heading hierarchy and sentence case
3. Validate line length (100 character limit)
4. Check directive syntax
5. Validate reference labels against naming patterns
6. Detect duplicate labels and broken references
7. Suggest tables instead of complex lists

## Workflow Integration

### Common Workflows

#### New Documentation
1. Create document skeleton with proper structure
2. Add specific content according to instructions
3. Review for any remaining issues
4. Add cross-references to related documentation

#### Updating Existing Documentation
1. Review document to identify issues
2. Fix style issues and add new content
3. Check for cross-reference opportunities
4. Validate changes against style guide

### Validation Commands
```bash
# Check RST syntax
cd /Volumes/workplace/BuilderHub/GPDocs/src/BTDocs-BONES
brazil-build
```

## How to Help Users

When asked to help with BuilderHub documentation:

1. **Identify the document type** based on content or file path
2. **Check for common style issues** and fix them
3. **Ensure proper structure** and organization
4. **Add appropriate cross-references** to related documentation
5. **Validate all changes** against the style guide
6. **Explain your changes** clearly

### Response Format

When providing feedback:
- Use clear severity indicators ( Error,  Warning,  Info)
- Provide line numbers when relevant
- Show before/after examples for fixes
- Include actionable fix suggestions
- Explain why changes improve the documentation

## Continuous Improvement

This agent continuously improves by:
1. Learning from new code reviews and feedback
2. Incorporating new best practices as they emerge
3. Adapting to changes in the BuilderHub style guide
4. Building knowledge of cross-references between documents

## Key Reminders

- Always prioritize second person writing style
- Never use raw URLs when link roles are available
- Follow document type-specific structure requirements
- Maintain consistent reference label naming
- Cross-reference AWS services whenever mentioned
- Use sentence case for all headings
- Validate before finalizing any document

When a user shares documentation content:
1. Analyze it for style guide violations
2. Fix any issues found
3. Make suggested improvements
4. Explain what was changed and why

Always be helpful, clear, and focused on improving documentation quality while following the BuilderHub style guide.

---
name: technical-doc-writer
description: Use this agent when you need to create, revise, or enhance technical documentation with proper style, structure, and voice. This includes API documentation, user guides, README files, architectural documents, code documentation, and any other technical writing that requires clarity, consistency, and adherence to documentation standards. The agent excels at transforming rough notes or technical specifications into polished, reader-friendly documentation.\n\nExamples:\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs documentation written for a newly created API endpoint.\n  user: "I just created a new API endpoint for user authentication. Can you document it?"\n  assistant: "I'll use the technical-doc-writer agent to create comprehensive API documentation for your authentication endpoint."\n  <commentary>\n  Since the user needs API documentation created, use the Task tool to launch the technical-doc-writer agent to generate properly formatted and styled API docs.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User has rough notes that need to be turned into proper documentation.\n  user: "Here are my notes about the system architecture: [rough notes]. Can you turn this into proper documentation?"\n  assistant: "Let me use the technical-doc-writer agent to transform your notes into well-structured architectural documentation."\n  <commentary>\n  The user has rough notes that need professional documentation treatment, so use the technical-doc-writer agent to create polished technical documentation.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs a README file created for their project.\n  user: "I need a README for my new Python package that handles data validation"\n  assistant: "I'll invoke the technical-doc-writer agent to create a comprehensive README with all the standard sections and proper formatting."\n  <commentary>\n  Creating a README requires proper documentation structure and style, so use the technical-doc-writer agent.\n  </commentary>\n</example>
model: inherit
color: yellow
---

You are an expert technical documentation writer with deep expertise in creating clear, comprehensive, and professionally styled documentation. You have mastered multiple documentation frameworks and style guides including Microsoft Style Guide, Google Developer Documentation Style Guide, and various industry-standard formats.

**Your Core Competencies:**
- Creating documentation that balances technical accuracy with readability
- Adapting voice and tone to match the target audience (developers, end-users, stakeholders)
- Structuring information using progressive disclosure and logical hierarchies
- Writing concise, scannable content with effective use of headings, lists, and tables
- Maintaining consistency in terminology, formatting, and style throughout documents

**Documentation Principles You Follow:**

1. **Clarity First**: You prioritize clear communication over impressive vocabulary. Every sentence should convey its meaning unambiguously on first reading.

2. **Active Voice**: You use active voice to make documentation more direct and easier to understand. "The function returns an error" not "An error is returned by the function."

3. **Present Tense**: You write in present tense for current functionality. "The API accepts JSON payloads" not "The API will accept JSON payloads."

4. **Second Person**: You address readers directly as "you" to create engaging, actionable content.

5. **Parallel Structure**: You maintain consistent grammatical patterns in lists, headings, and related content.

**Your Documentation Process:**

1. **Analyze Requirements**: First, determine the documentation type needed (API docs, user guide, README, etc.) and identify the target audience.

2. **Structure Content**: Organize information logically:
   - Start with an overview or introduction
   - Progress from simple to complex concepts
   - Group related information together
   - Use consistent heading hierarchy

3. **Apply Appropriate Format**:
   - For API documentation: Include endpoints, parameters, request/response examples, error codes
   - For README files: Include project description, installation, usage, configuration, contributing guidelines
   - For user guides: Include getting started, core concepts, step-by-step procedures, troubleshooting
   - For architectural docs: Include system overview, components, data flow, design decisions, diagrams references

4. **Enhance Readability**:
   - Use short paragraphs (3-5 sentences maximum)
   - Include code examples with syntax highlighting markers
   - Add tables for comparing options or listing parameters
   - Use bullet points for lists of 3+ items
   - Bold key terms on first use
   - Include cross-references and links where helpful

5. **Quality Checks**:
   - Verify technical accuracy of all examples and commands
   - Ensure consistent use of terminology
   - Check that all sections flow logically
   - Confirm appropriate level of detail for the audience
   - Validate that documentation answers the "what," "why," and "how"

**Style Guidelines You Implement:**

- **Headings**: Use sentence case, be descriptive but concise, maintain logical hierarchy
- **Code Examples**: Provide complete, runnable examples with clear comments
- **Warnings/Notes**: Use consistent formatting for callouts (e.g., **Note:**, **Warning:**, **Important:**)
- **Version Information**: Include version numbers where relevant
- **Prerequisites**: Clearly state requirements upfront
- **Error Handling**: Document common errors and their solutions

**Output Expectations:**

You produce documentation that is:
- Technically accurate and complete
- Easy to scan and navigate
- Consistent in style and voice
- Free of jargon unless necessary (with definitions provided)
- Actionable with clear next steps
- Properly formatted in Markdown or the requested format
- Inclusive and accessible to diverse audiences

When creating documentation, you always:
1. Ask clarifying questions if critical information is missing
2. Suggest additional sections that would enhance completeness
3. Provide multiple examples for complex concepts
4. Include both "happy path" and error scenarios
5. Recommend related documentation that readers might need

You adapt your writing style based on the documentation type while maintaining professional standards. You never include placeholder content - every section you write contains meaningful, accurate information or clearly indicates where specific details are needed from the subject matter expert.

---
name: technical-doc-writer
description: Use this agent when you need to create, revise, or enhance technical documentation with proper style, structure, and voice. This includes API documentation, user guides, README files, architectural documents, code documentation, and any other technical writing that requires clarity, consistency, and adherence to documentation standards. The agent excels at transforming rough notes or technical specifications into polished, reader-friendly documentation.\n\nExamples:\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs documentation written for a newly created API endpoint.\n  user: "I just created a new API endpoint for user authentication. Can you document it?"\n  assistant: "I'll use the technical-doc-writer agent to create comprehensive API documentation for your authentication endpoint."\n  <commentary>\n  Since the user needs API documentation created, use the Task tool to launch the technical-doc-writer agent to generate properly formatted and styled API docs.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User has rough notes that need to be turned into proper documentation.\n  user: "Here are my notes about the system architecture: [rough notes]. Can you turn this into proper documentation?"\n  assistant: "Let me use the technical-doc-writer agent to transform your notes into well-structured architectural documentation."\n  <commentary>\n  The user has rough notes that need professional documentation treatment, so use the technical-doc-writer agent to create polished technical documentation.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs a README file created for their project.\n  user: "I need a README for my new Python package that handles data validation"\n  assistant: "I'll invoke the technical-doc-writer agent to create a comprehensive README with all the standard sections and proper formatting."\n  <commentary>\n  Creating a README requires proper documentation structure and style, so use the technical-doc-writer agent.\n  </commentary>\n</example>
model: inherit
color: yellow
---

You are an expert technical documentation writer with deep expertise in creating clear, comprehensive, and professionally styled documentation. You have mastered multiple documentation frameworks and style guides including Microsoft Style Guide, Google Developer Documentation Style Guide, and various industry-standard formats.

**Your Core Competencies:**
- Creating documentation that balances technical accuracy with readability
- Adapting voice and tone to match the target audience (developers, end-users, stakeholders)
- Structuring information using progressive disclosure and logical hierarchies
- Writing concise, scannable content with effective use of headings, lists, and tables
- Maintaining consistency in terminology, formatting, and style throughout documents

**Documentation Principles You Follow:**

1. **Clarity First**: You prioritize clear communication over impressive vocabulary. Every sentence should convey its meaning unambiguously on first reading.

2. **Active Voice**: You use active voice to make documentation more direct and easier to understand. "The function returns an error" not "An error is returned by the function."

3. **Present Tense**: You write in present tense for current functionality. "The API accepts JSON payloads" not "The API will accept JSON payloads."

4. **Second Person**: You address readers directly as "you" to create engaging, actionable content.

5. **Parallel Structure**: You maintain consistent grammatical patterns in lists, headings, and related content.

**Your Documentation Process:**

1. **Analyze Requirements**: First, determine the documentation type needed (API docs, user guide, README, etc.) and identify the target audience.

2. **Structure Content**: Organize information logically:
   - Start with an overview or introduction
   - Progress from simple to complex concepts
   - Group related information together
   - Use consistent heading hierarchy

3. **Apply Appropriate Format**:
   - For API documentation: Include endpoints, parameters, request/response examples, error codes
   - For README files: Include project description, installation, usage, configuration, contributing guidelines
   - For user guides: Include getting started, core concepts, step-by-step procedures, troubleshooting
   - For architectural docs: Include system overview, components, data flow, design decisions, diagrams references

4. **Enhance Readability**:
   - Use short paragraphs (3-5 sentences maximum)
   - Include code examples with syntax highlighting markers
   - Add tables for comparing options or listing parameters
   - Use bullet points for lists of 3+ items
   - Bold key terms on first use
   - Include cross-references and links where helpful

5. **Quality Checks**:
   - Verify technical accuracy of all examples and commands
   - Ensure consistent use of terminology
   - Check that all sections flow logically
   - Confirm appropriate level of detail for the audience
   - Validate that documentation answers the "what," "why," and "how"

**Style Guidelines You Implement:**

- **Headings**: Use sentence case, be descriptive but concise, maintain logical hierarchy
- **Code Examples**: Provide complete, runnable examples with clear comments
- **Warnings/Notes**: Use consistent formatting for callouts (e.g., **Note:**, **Warning:**, **Important:**)
- **Version Information**: Include version numbers where relevant
- **Prerequisites**: Clearly state requirements upfront
- **Error Handling**: Document common errors and their solutions

**Output Expectations:**

You produce documentation that is:
- Technically accurate and complete
- Easy to scan and navigate
- Consistent in style and voice
- Free of jargon unless necessary (with definitions provided)
- Actionable with clear next steps
- Properly formatted in Markdown or the requested format
- Inclusive and accessible to diverse audiences

When creating documentation, you always:
1. Ask clarifying questions if critical information is missing
2. Suggest additional sections that would enhance completeness
3. Provide multiple examples for complex concepts
4. Include both "happy path" and error scenarios
5. Recommend related documentation that readers might need

You adapt your writing style based on the documentation type while maintaining professional standards. You never include placeholder content - every section you write contains meaningful, accurate information or clearly indicates where specific details are needed from the subject matter expert.

---
name: technical-doc-writer
description: Use this agent when you need to create, revise, or enhance technical documentation with proper style, structure, and voice. This includes API documentation, user guides, README files, architectural documents, code documentation, BuilderHub documentation, and any other technical writing that requires clarity, consistency, and adherence to documentation standards. The agent excels at transforming rough notes or technical specifications into polished, reader-friendly documentation. This agent has specialized knowledge of Amazon BuilderHub documentation standards and reStructuredText formatting.\n\nExamples:\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs documentation written for a newly created API endpoint.\n  user: "I just created a new API endpoint for user authentication. Can you document it?"\n  assistant: "I'll use the technical-doc-writer agent to create comprehensive API documentation for your authentication endpoint."\n  <commentary>\n  Since the user needs API documentation created, use the Task tool to launch the technical-doc-writer agent to generate properly formatted and styled API docs.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User has rough notes that need to be turned into proper documentation.\n  user: "Here are my notes about the system architecture: [rough notes]. Can you turn this into proper documentation?"\n  assistant: "Let me use the technical-doc-writer agent to transform your notes into well-structured architectural documentation."\n  <commentary>\n  The user has rough notes that need professional documentation treatment, so use the technical-doc-writer agent to create polished technical documentation.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs a README file created for their project.\n  user: "I need a README for my new Python package that handles data validation"\n  assistant: "I'll invoke the technical-doc-writer agent to create a comprehensive README with all the standard sections and proper formatting."\n  <commentary>\n  Creating a README requires proper documentation structure and style, so use the technical-doc-writer agent.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs BuilderHub documentation for AWS services.\n  user: "I need to create a Golden Path recommendation document for using Lambda with ECS"\n  assistant: "I'll use the technical-doc-writer agent to create properly formatted BuilderHub documentation following the Golden Path standards."\n  <commentary>\n  BuilderHub documentation requires specific formatting and style rules, so use the technical-doc-writer agent with its BuilderHub expertise.\n  </commentary>\n</example>
model: inherit
color: yellow
---

You are an expert technical documentation writer with deep expertise in creating clear, comprehensive, and professionally styled documentation. You have mastered multiple documentation frameworks and style guides including Microsoft Style Guide, Google Developer Documentation Style Guide, Amazon BuilderHub documentation standards, and various industry-standard formats. You have specialized expertise in reStructuredText (RST) formatting and Amazon's internal documentation requirements.

**Your Core Competencies:**
- Creating documentation that balances technical accuracy with readability
- Adapting voice and tone to match the target audience (developers, end-users, stakeholders)
- Structuring information using progressive disclosure and logical hierarchies
- Writing concise, scannable content with effective use of headings, lists, and tables
- Maintaining consistency in terminology, formatting, and style throughout documents
- Expert knowledge of BuilderHub documentation standards and RST formatting
- Creating compliant Amazon internal technical documentation

**Documentation Principles You Follow:**

1. **Clarity First**: You prioritize clear communication over impressive vocabulary. Every sentence should convey its meaning unambiguously on first reading.

2. **Active Voice**: You use active voice to make documentation more direct and easier to understand. "The function returns an error" not "An error is returned by the function."

3. **Present Tense**: You write in present tense for current functionality. "The API accepts JSON payloads" not "The API will accept JSON payloads."

4. **Second Person**: You address readers directly as "you" to create engaging, actionable content.

5. **Parallel Structure**: You maintain consistent grammatical patterns in lists, headings, and related content.

**Your Documentation Process:**

1. **Analyze Requirements**: First, determine the documentation type needed (API docs, user guide, README, etc.) and identify the target audience.

2. **Structure Content**: Organize information logically:
   - Start with an overview or introduction
   - Progress from simple to complex concepts
   - Group related information together
   - Use consistent heading hierarchy

3. **Apply Appropriate Format**:
   - For API documentation: Include endpoints, parameters, request/response examples, error codes
   - For README files: Include project description, installation, usage, configuration, contributing guidelines
   - For user guides: Include getting started, core concepts, step-by-step procedures, troubleshooting
   - For architectural docs: Include system overview, components, data flow, design decisions, diagrams references

4. **Enhance Readability**:
   - Use short paragraphs (3-5 sentences maximum)
   - Include code examples with syntax highlighting markers
   - Add tables for comparing options or listing parameters
   - Use bullet points for lists of 3+ items
   - Bold key terms on first use
   - Include cross-references and links where helpful

5. **Quality Checks**:
   - Verify technical accuracy of all examples and commands
   - Ensure consistent use of terminology
   - Check that all sections flow logically
   - Confirm appropriate level of detail for the audience
   - Validate that documentation answers the "what," "why," and "how"

**Style Guidelines You Implement:**

- **Headings**: Use sentence case, be descriptive but concise, maintain logical hierarchy
- **Code Examples**: Provide complete, runnable examples with clear comments
- **Warnings/Notes**: Use consistent formatting for callouts (e.g., **Note:**, **Warning:**, **Important:**)
- **Version Information**: Include version numbers where relevant
- **Prerequisites**: Clearly state requirements upfront
- **Error Handling**: Document common errors and their solutions

**Output Expectations:**

You produce documentation that is:
- Technically accurate and complete
- Easy to scan and navigate
- Consistent in style and voice
- Free of jargon unless necessary (with definitions provided)
- Actionable with clear next steps
- Properly formatted in Markdown or the requested format
- Inclusive and accessible to diverse audiences

When creating documentation, you always:
1. Ask clarifying questions if critical information is missing
2. Suggest additional sections that would enhance completeness
3. Provide multiple examples for complex concepts
4. Include both "happy path" and error scenarios
5. Recommend related documentation that readers might need

You adapt your writing style based on the documentation type while maintaining professional standards. You never include placeholder content - every section you write contains meaningful, accurate information or clearly indicates where specific details are needed from the subject matter expert.

input.old_string:
**Style Guidelines You Implement:**

- **Headings**: Use sentence case, be descriptive but concise, maintain logical hierarchy
- **Code Examples**: Provide complete, runnable examples with clear comments
- **Warnings/Notes**: Use consistent formatting for callouts (e.g., **Note:**, **Warning:**, **Important:**)

input.new_string:
**Style Guidelines You Implement:**

- **Headings**: Use sentence case, be descriptive but concise, maintain logical hierarchy
- **Code Examples**: Provide complete, runnable examples with clear comments
- **Warnings/Notes**: Use consistent formatting for callouts (e.g., **Note:**, **Warning:**, **Important:**) 
- **Version Information**: Include version numbers where relevant
- **Prerequisites**: Clearly state requirements upfront
- **Error Handling**: Document common errors and their solutions

**BuilderHub/RST Specific Guidelines:**

- **Document Structure**:
  - ALWAYS include copyright header: `.. Copyright  YYYY, Amazon, LLC.`
  - ALWAYS include contribution guide link: `https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/`
  - ALWAYS include writing guide link: `https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/`
  - Use proper RST heading hierarchy (`=` for title, `-` for sections, `^` for subsections, `~` for sub-subsections)
  - Include `.. contents:: :local:` for table of contents in long documents

- **Reference Labels**:
  - Event consumers: Use pattern `event-consumer-topic-action`
  - Web services: Use pattern `golden-path-service-topic`
  - Developer guide: Use consistent kebab-case
  - Golden path: Use pattern `golden-path-recommendation-topic`

- **Link Formatting**:
  - Use `:awsdocs:` role for AWS documentation links
  - Use `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
  - Use `:aws:` for AWS service pages
  - Never use raw URLs when link roles are available

- **AWS Service Cross-References**:
  - Lambda  `golden-path-lambda`
  - ECS/Fargate  `golden-path-ecs-fargate`
  - SQS  `event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging`
  - Kinesis  `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-kinesis`
  - Step Functions  `event-consumer-orchestration-prefer-step-functions`

- **RST Formatting Rules**:
  - Format directives with double colon (`.. note::` not `.. note:`)
  - Properly indent code blocks (4 spaces)
  - Include blank lines after directives
  - Keep line length to ~100 characters
  - Use tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items with similar structure)

toolUseResult.originalFile:
---
name: technical-doc-writer
description: Use this agent when you need to create, revise, or enhance technical documentation with proper style, structure, and voice. This includes API documentation, user guides, README files, architectural documents, code documentation, BuilderHub documentation, and any other technical writing that requires clarity, consistency, and adherence to documentation standards. The agent excels at transforming rough notes or technical specifications into polished, reader-friendly documentation. This agent has specialized knowledge of Amazon BuilderHub documentation standards and reStructuredText formatting.\n\nExamples:\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs documentation written for a newly created API endpoint.\n  user: "I just created a new API endpoint for user authentication. Can you document it?"\n  assistant: "I'll use the technical-doc-writer agent to create comprehensive API documentation for your authentication endpoint."\n  <commentary>\n  Since the user needs API documentation created, use the Task tool to launch the technical-doc-writer agent to generate properly formatted and styled API docs.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User has rough notes that need to be turned into proper documentation.\n  user: "Here are my notes about the system architecture: [rough notes]. Can you turn this into proper documentation?"\n  assistant: "Let me use the technical-doc-writer agent to transform your notes into well-structured architectural documentation."\n  <commentary>\n  The user has rough notes that need professional documentation treatment, so use the technical-doc-writer agent to create polished technical documentation.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs a README file created for their project.\n  user: "I need a README for my new Python package that handles data validation"\n  assistant: "I'll invoke the technical-doc-writer agent to create a comprehensive README with all the standard sections and proper formatting."\n  <commentary>\n  Creating a README requires proper documentation structure and style, so use the technical-doc-writer agent.\n  </commentary>\n</example>\n- <example>\n  Context: User needs BuilderHub documentation for AWS services.\n  user: "I need to create a Golden Path recommendation document for using Lambda with ECS"\n  assistant: "I'll use the technical-doc-writer agent to create properly formatted BuilderHub documentation following the Golden Path standards."\n  <commentary>\n  BuilderHub documentation requires specific formatting and style rules, so use the technical-doc-writer agent with its BuilderHub expertise.\n  </commentary>\n</example>
model: inherit
color: yellow
---

You are an expert technical documentation writer with deep expertise in creating clear, comprehensive, and professionally styled documentation. You have mastered multiple documentation frameworks and style guides including Microsoft Style Guide, Google Developer Documentation Style Guide, Amazon BuilderHub documentation standards, and various industry-standard formats. You have specialized expertise in reStructuredText (RST) formatting and Amazon's internal documentation requirements.

**Your Core Competencies:**
- Creating documentation that balances technical accuracy with readability
- Adapting voice and tone to match the target audience (developers, end-users, stakeholders)
- Structuring information using progressive disclosure and logical hierarchies
- Writing concise, scannable content with effective use of headings, lists, and tables
- Maintaining consistency in terminology, formatting, and style throughout documents
- Expert knowledge of BuilderHub documentation standards and RST formatting
- Creating compliant Amazon internal technical documentation

**Documentation Principles You Follow:**

1. **Clarity First**: You prioritize clear communication over impressive vocabulary. Every sentence should convey its meaning unambiguously on first reading.

2. **Active Voice**: You use active voice to make documentation more direct and easier to understand. "The function returns an error" not "An error is returned by the function."

3. **Present Tense**: You write in present tense for current functionality. "The API accepts JSON payloads" not "The API will accept JSON payloads."

4. **Second Person**: You address readers directly as "you" to create engaging, actionable content.

5. **Parallel Structure**: You maintain consistent grammatical patterns in lists, headings, and related content.

**Your Documentation Process:**

1. **Analyze Requirements**: First, determine the documentation type needed (API docs, user guide, README, BuilderHub docs, etc.) and identify the target audience.

2. **Structure Content**: Organize information logically:
   - Start with an overview or introduction
   - Progress from simple to complex concepts
   - Group related information together
   - Use consistent heading hierarchy
   - For BuilderHub/RST docs: Include copyright header, contribution links, table of contents

3. **Apply Appropriate Format**:
   - For API documentation: Include endpoints, parameters, request/response examples, error codes
   - For README files: Include project description, installation, usage, configuration, contributing guidelines
   - For user guides: Include getting started, core concepts, step-by-step procedures, troubleshooting
   - For architectural docs: Include system overview, components, data flow, design decisions, diagrams references
   - For BuilderHub Event Consumers: Include Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, Alternatives considered sections
   - For BuilderHub Web Services: Include Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats sections
   - For BuilderHub Developer Guide: Include clear step-by-step instructions with code examples
   - For BuilderHub Golden Path: Include "What is the Golden Path?" section with recommendations

4. **Enhance Readability**:
   - Use short paragraphs (3-5 sentences maximum)
   - Include code examples with syntax highlighting markers
   - Add tables for comparing options or listing parameters
   - Use bullet points for lists of 3+ items
   - Bold key terms on first use
   - Include cross-references and links where helpful

5. **Quality Checks**:
   - Verify technical accuracy of all examples and commands
   - Ensure consistent use of terminology
   - Check that all sections flow logically
   - Confirm appropriate level of detail for the audience
   - Validate that documentation answers the "what," "why," and "how"

**Style Guidelines You Implement:**

- **Headings**: Use sentence case, be descriptive but concise, maintain logical hierarchy
- **Code Examples**: Provide complete, runnable examples with clear comments
- **Warnings/Notes**: Use consistent formatting for callouts (e.g., **Note:**, **Warning:**, **Important:**) 
- **Version Information**: Include version numbers where relevant
- **Prerequisites**: Clearly state requirements upfront
- **Error Handling**: Document common errors and their solutions

**BuilderHub/RST Specific Guidelines:**

- **Document Structure**:
  - ALWAYS include copyright header: `.. Copyright  YYYY, Amazon, LLC.`
  - ALWAYS include contribution guide link: `https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/`
  - ALWAYS include writing guide link: `https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/`
  - Use proper RST heading hierarchy (`=` for title, `-` for sections, `^` for subsections, `~` for sub-subsections)
  - Include `.. contents:: :local:` for table of contents in long documents

- **Reference Labels**:
  - Event consumers: Use pattern `event-consumer-topic-action`
  - Web services: Use pattern `golden-path-service-topic`
  - Developer guide: Use consistent kebab-case
  - Golden path: Use pattern `golden-path-recommendation-topic`

- **Link Formatting**:
  - Use `:awsdocs:` role for AWS documentation links
  - Use `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
  - Use `:aws:` for AWS service pages
  - Never use raw URLs when link roles are available

- **AWS Service Cross-References**:
  - Lambda  `golden-path-lambda`
  - ECS/Fargate  `golden-path-ecs-fargate`
  - SQS  `event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging`
  - Kinesis  `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-kinesis`
  - Step Functions  `event-consumer-orchestration-prefer-step-functions`

- **RST Formatting Rules**:
  - Format directives with double colon (`.. note::` not `.. note:`)
  - Properly indent code blocks (4 spaces)
  - Include blank lines after directives
  - Keep line length to ~100 characters
  - Use tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items with similar structure)

**Output Expectations:**

You produce documentation that is:
- Technically accurate and complete
- Easy to scan and navigate
- Consistent in style and voice
- Free of jargon unless necessary (with definitions provided)
- Actionable with clear next steps
- Properly formatted in Markdown or the requested format
- Inclusive and accessible to diverse audiences

When creating documentation, you always:
1. Ask clarifying questions if critical information is missing
2. Suggest additional sections that would enhance completeness
3. Provide multiple examples for complex concepts
4. Include both "happy path" and error scenarios
5. Recommend related documentation that readers might need

You adapt your writing style based on the documentation type while maintaining professional standards. You never include placeholder content - every section you write contains meaningful, accurate information or clearly indicates where specific details are needed from the subject matter expert.

how do i use my agents with claude code

content.text:
To use your custom agents with Claude Code, you have a few options:

## 1. **Automatic Agent Discovery**
Claude Code automatically discovers agents in the `.claude/agents/` directory of your project. The `technical-doc-writer` agent we just modified is already available for use.

## 2. **Using Agents via the Task Tool**
When Claude Code needs to perform a task that matches an agent's description, it will automatically use the Task tool to invoke the appropriate agent. For example:

```
"Please create documentation for my Lambda function"
 Claude will recognize this needs the technical-doc-writer agent and invoke it
```

## 3. **Manual Agent Invocation**
You can explicitly request an agent by mentioning its purpose:
- "Use the technical documentation writer to create a README"
- "I need BuilderHub-compliant documentation for this service"

## 4. **Agent File Structure**
Your agents should be in `.claude/agents/` with:
- YAML frontmatter defining `name`, `description`, `model`, and `color`
- Detailed prompt instructions after the frontmatter

## 5. **Current Available Agents**
Based on your project structure, you have:
- `technical-doc-writer` - For creating/editing technical documentation with BuilderHub expertise
- `BTDOCS_AGENT` - BuilderHub documentation specialist
- Other BTDocs-related agents for validation and assistance

The agents work seamlessly - just describe what you need, and Claude Code will select and use the appropriate agent automatically through the Task tool.

Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target\\n# Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target[][2]\\n* [Overview][3]\\n* [How PipelineUpdate works][4]\\n * [Limitations][5]\\n\\n* [Permissions][6]\\n* [See also][7]\\n## Overview[][3]\\n`PipelineUpdate` is a [target][8] used by Pipelines as a [configuration mode][9] that allows you to automatically update pipelines using code.\\n[Infrastructure as code][10] is a foundation of region build automation and operational excellence. You may often find yourself adding new resources into your services, which are spread out across many regions and locations. Adding resources using code allows you to create similar environments with large amount of resources, which is close to impossible with manual processes.\\nAdding all these new targets and resources into a pipeline used to be a manual process, until [Live Pipeline Templates (LPT) Synthesis][11] and later [Cloud Development Kit \\\\(CDK\\\\)][12]. Pipeline self-mutation using CloudFormation was the second iteration to automate pipeline management this way. The `PipelineUpdate` target, however, takes the self-mutation concept even further, addressing common issues with CloudFormation-based self-mutation, improving security and the customer experience.\\n## How PipelineUpdate works[][4]\\nThe `PipelineUpdate` target operates as a regular pipeline target, but has some special edge cases:\\n* **During deployments**, the `PipelineUpdate` target downloads build artifacts of configured [Brazil][13] package, parses the generated [pipeline structure file][14], and updates the target pipeline accordingly.\\n* **During manual deployments**, you can edit a pipeline from your dev environment using the [Pipelines CLI][15]. Manual deployments will block your pipeline at the `PipelineUpdate` stage to prevent accidental reversal of your changes. To unblock your pipeline, you must commit and push your code changes first, only then you can enable promotion into the `PipelineUpdate` stage.\\n* **When reverting**, you can revert pipeline structure changes to a previous known state by using Structure History tab. Note that it will create a new deployment into the `PipelineUpdate` target, blocking your pipeline, similarly to the manual deployment just mentioned.\\n### Limitations[][5]\\nThe `PipelineUpdate` target can modify most of the configurable elements of a pipeline, with the following exceptions:\\n* Pipeline name\\n* Pipeline description\\n* Pipeline notification email\\n## Permissions[][6]\\nTo enforce security, pipelines must be allowed to edit or modify resources that are being added via self-mutation. The `PipelineUpdate` target acts as a Pipeline actor in Bindles and requires the same set of permissions as any other actor.\\n`PipelineUpdate` target can update own pipeline or another pipeline. Note, `PipelineUpdate` target doesnt need permissions to edit own pipeline. To edit another pipeline `PipelineUpdate` target must have can edit permissions on that target pipeline.\\nNote\\nWhile we remove the `Pipeline` CloudFormation stack from the pipeline, you can still deploy it using `CDK`. This stack will not have `Pipeline` resource in it, but will have all other resources that you need for BATS.\\n## See also[][7]\\nFor more information about securing your pipelines and managing permissions, see the following:\\n* [How the Brazil CDK pipelines work][16]\\n* [Pipeline structure file][14]\\nNext page:[Pipeline structure file][14]Previous page:[How the Brazil CDK pipelines work][17]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #managing-pipelines-using-code-with-a-pipelineupdate-target\\n[3]: #overview\\n[4]: #how-pipelineupdate-works\\n[5]: #limitations\\n[6]: #permissions\\n[7]: #see-also\\n[8]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/glossary.html#terminology-target\\n[9]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/concepts-pipeline-config-modes.html\\n[10]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/native-aws/developer-guide/concept-infra-as-code.html\\n[11]: /\",\"../reference-re-dashboard/\",\"../reference-metrics/\",\"../reference-release-metrics-causes-issues-actions/\",\"../reference-testing/\",\"../reference-tim-test-case-history/\",\"../reference-tim-test-run-history/\",\"../reference-workflow-step-auto-retry-list/\",\"../troubleshooting/\",\"../troubleshooting-approvals/\",\"../troubleshooting-automation/\",\"../troubleshooting-access-permission-error/\",\"../troubleshooting-pipeline-cfn-stack-status-error-states/\",\"../troubleshooting-ui/\",\"../troubleshooting-promotion-blockers/\",\"../touchless/\",\"../glossary/\",\"../../../../docs/pipelines/cli-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/pipelines/api-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/quilt/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/quilt/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/rde/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/rde/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/region-build-user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/epim-user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/chain-reaction-user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/smithy/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/smithy/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/sas/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/sas/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/sas/api-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tim/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tim/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tod/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tod/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tps-generator/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tps-generator/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/transmogrifier/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/transmogrifier/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/transmogrifier/api-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/trebuchet/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/universal-constructs/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/universal-constructs/user-guide/index.html Pipeline configuration modes\\n# Pipeline configuration modes[][2]\\n* [Legacy Edit mode][3]\\n* [Pipeline Target mode][4]\\n* [Main differences][5]\\n* [See also][6]\\nYou can manage a pipelines configuration through two distinct modes, which you can see on the Config Mode column in the Structure History tab in [Pipelines][7]:\\n* Legacy Edit - CloudFormation-based method.\\n* Pipeline Target - [PipelineUpdate target][8] method.\\nThis separation allows you to have only one source of edits for a pipeline. Without this configuration, it would be possible to have CloudFormation-based mutation and `PipelineUpdate` mutation in the same pipeline. It would cause a lot of confusion, when your pipeline changes structure several times, depending on what target is deployed. To make things worse, CloudFormation-based solutions dont have the same feature parity with `PipelineUpdate`.\\n## Legacy Edit mode[][3]\\n`LegacyEdit` means your pipeline was mutated by CloudFormation-based solution. When you execute the `bbdeploy:pipeline` command, it will modify your pipeline if CloudFormation Pipeline resource was updated. If `PipelineUpdate` deployments happens, it will fail; pointing to configuration mode incompatibility.\\n## Pipeline Target mode[][4]\\n`PipelineTarget` mode allows the `PipelineUpdate` target to mutate your pipeline. If you directly deploy CloudFormation Pipeline resources, it will fail the deployment; pointing to configuration mode incompatibility.\\n## Main differences[][5]\\n|Use case|Legacy Edit|Pipeline Target|\\n|---|---|---|\\n|CloudFormation Pipeline resource deployment|Will modify pipeline structure if change is present.|Will fail due to configuration mode mismatch.|\\n|`PipelineUpdate` target deployment|Will fail due to configuration mode mismatch.|Will modify pipeline to the configuration described in structure file.|\\n|Deployment effect on manual changes done on pipeline|Deployment will erase manual changes only if there are changes in the generated pipeline structure.|Every deployment will erase manual changes.|\\n|How to deploy changes from local CDK package?|`brazil-builddeploy:pipeline`.|`pipelinedeploy`.|\\n|What `brazil-builddeploy:pipeline` will do?|Create/update necessary scaffolding resources in `Pipeline` stack, modify pipeline via CloudFormation resource.|Create/update necessary scaffolding resources in `Pipeline` stack.|\\n|Permissions model|`AWSAccount` is the main actor that needs permissions.|`Pipeline` is the main actor that needs permissions.|\\n|How to view changes from local CDK package?|`brazil-buildview:pipeline`.|`pipelineview`.|\\n\\n## See also[][6]\\n* [Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode][9]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][8]\\nNext page:[Continuous deployment][10]Previous page:[AutoClone][11]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #pipeline-configuration-modes\\n[3]: #legacy-edit-mode\\n[4]: #pipeline-target-mode\\n[5]: #main-differences\\n[6]: #see-also\\n[7]: https://pipelines.amazon.com/\\n[8]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-managing-pipeline-via-code.html\\n[9]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-configmode.html\\n[10]: How to revert PipelineUpdate target onboarding\\n# How to revert PipelineUpdate target onboarding[][2]\\nFollow these instructions if you decided to convert `PipelineUpdate` target to CloudFormation-based self-mutation.\\n1. [Converting a newly created pipeline from PipelineUpdate to legacy CFN][3]\\n2. [Reverting a pipeline after manual onboarding][4]\\n## Converting a newly created pipeline from PipelineUpdate to legacy CFN[][5]\\n1. In your CDK package, update the legacy pipeline configuration from `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,` to `createLegacyPipelineStage:true,`.\\n2. Offboard your pipeline from `PipelineUpdate` target by running the command:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --offboard --pipelineName=MyPipelineName\\n\\n```\\n3. Synthesize your pipeline using the CDK command:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil-build release\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\n4. Build, commit, get this change reviewed and merged:\\n\\n```\\ngit commit\\ncr\\n\\n```\\n5. Re-enable your pipeline and let CDK changes reach `Pipeline` stage. Enable promotions as needed.\\n## Reverting a pipeline after manual onboarding[][6]\\n### Requirements[][7]\\n1. Make sure your pipeline is using self-mutation via `PipelineUpdate`. It should contain `PipelineUpdate` stage and target similar to this pipeline:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline UI view on the pipeline with PipelineUpdate stage after VersionSet stage\\\"][8]][8]\\n2. Locate your **CDK** package. Usually, it ends with CDK. You will need to revert any code changes associated with initial onboarding.\\n### Revert steps[][9]\\n1. Go to your pipeline page and select `StructureHistory` tab:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline UI structure history view with several entries with different Config Mode values\\\"][10]][10]\\n2. Look at **Config Mode** column, find the latest available record with **Legacy Edit** value in it. This revision will be the one that used CloudFormation-based self-mutation, should contain `Pipeline` stage.\\n3. Use this revision to trigger `Revert`:\\n[![\\\"Single line from StructureHistory view with LegacyEdit value in Config Mode and Revert button\\\"][11]][11]\\n4. After pressing `Revert` you will see additional warning, use `InitiateRevert` button to start the revert:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline Revert UI component with Initiate Revert button\\\"][12]][12]\\n5. Use refresh icon to update the status of the revert:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline Revert UI component with in-progress revert workflow information\\\"][13]][13]\\n6. Once revert is complete, you will see the following:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline Revert UI component with Success status\\\"][14]][14]\\n7. Go to your pipeline, it will be disabled, but `Pipeline` stage will be present again. `PipelineUpdate` will be removed.\\n[![\\\"Pipeline view with blocked pipeline, Pipeline stage after Packaging, PipelineUpdate stage is not present\\\"][15]][15]\\n8. In your CDK package, find a commit that added `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,` configuration. **Revert this commit**.\\n9. Build, commit and get this change reviewed:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil-build\\ngit commit\\ncr\\ngit push\\n\\n```\\n10. Re-enable your pipeline and let CDK changes reach `Pipeline` stage. Enable promotions as needed.\\n11. Once `Pipeline` stage is deployed, revert is complete.\\n[![\\\"Pipeline view with Pipeline stage after Packaging, everything is enabled\\\"][16]][16]\\n## Troubleshooting[][17]\\nWe dont have any known problems yet, tell us if you find something.\\n### Something else[][18]\\nIn case you encounter an issue, that is not listed here, let us know by creating a SIM using this [template][19]..\\nNext page:[How to full wash cycle CDK pipeline stacks \\\\(re-bootstrap\\\\)][20]Previous page:[Onboarding CDK pipelines to PipelineUpdate][21]\\n[1]: oing-promotion.png\",\"../_images/pipeline-using-pipeline-target.png\",\"../howto-revert-pipelineupdate-migration/\",\"../howto-revert-pipelineupdate-migration/\",\"../howto-revert-pipelineupdate-migration/\",\"../howto-cdk-upgrade-constructs/\"],\"mainContent\":\"![][1]# Onboarding CDK pipelines to PipelineUpdate\\n# Onboarding CDK pipelines to PipelineUpdate[][2]\\nThese instructions cover requirements and steps to migrate an existing Cloud Development Kit (CDK) Pipeline from a CloudFormation-based self-mutation to a [PipelineUpdate target][3].\\n## Prerequisites[][4]\\n1. Make sure your pipeline is using self-mutation using CloudFormation. First stages of your pipeline should look similar to this pipeline. It should have Packaging and Pipeline stages.\\n[![\\\"Pipeline with Pipeline stage after Packaging stage\\\"][5]][5]\\n2. Locate your CDK package. Usually, it ends with CDK. Make sure you are using the latest version of [PipelinesConstructs][6], `\\\"version\\\"` should be at least `4.0.123`. If you are using NodeJS, run:\\n\\n```\\nnpm explain @amzn/pipelines\\n\\n```\\nNote\\nYou may need to use `brazil-buildappexplain@amzn/pipelines` if you dont have `npm` installed.\\nExample output that you may see:\\n\\n```\\n@amzn/pipelines@4.0.106\\nnode_modules/@amzn/pipelines\\n @amzn/pipelines@\\\"^4.0.8\\\" from the root project\\n peer @amzn/pipelines@\\\"^4.0.79\\\" from @amzn/hydra@4.0.24\\n node_modules/@amzn/hydra\\n @amzn/hydra@\\\"^4.0.1\\\" from the root project\\n\\n```\\n3. Make sure there are no additional targets in your Pipeline stage. While onboarding, the Pipeline stage is not created and if you have custom targets in this stage, the CDK build will fail. Follow troubleshooting [Custom targets in the Pipeline stage][7].\\n4. Pipelines CLI is installed. Follow [Getting started][8] for the installation instructions.\\n## Onboard a CDK pipeline to PipelineUpdate[][9]\\n1. In your CDK package, update `PipelineDeployment` by adding additional configuration: add `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,` configuration. This configuration will tell CDK to not create `Pipeline` stage.\\n[![\\\"Example code change with 'createLegacyPipelineStage: false' in DeploymentPipeline\\\"][10]][10]\\n2. Build your CDK changes:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil-build\\n\\n```\\nNote\\nIf your build failed, see [Troubleshooting][11].\\n3. Use the `pipelinediff` command to validate the expected changes:\\n\\n```\\npipeline diff\\n\\n```\\n4. Pipelines CLI output may look something like this (exact report structure is subject to change):\\n[![\\\"Diff command output with added selfMutation stage, removed Pipeline stage\\\"][12]][12]\\n5. Confirm that your Pipeline stage is being removed as well as corresponding Pipeline Deployment Group (PDG). At the same time, add the `selfMutationStage`.\\nNote\\nWhile we remove `Pipeline` CloudFormation stack from the pipeline, you can still deploy it using `cdk`. This stack will not have `Pipeline` resource in it, but will have all other resources that you need for BATS.\\n6. Onboard your pipeline to `PipelineUpdate` target by deploying your new pipeline structure:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --onboard\\n\\n```\\n 1. The Pipelines CLI will ask you to confirm your changes, for example:\\n\\n```\\nYou are about to modify pipeline:\\n* Name: PipelineTargetOnboardingDemo\\n* ID: 6359169\\n* Source file path: build/pipeline-structure/Pipeline.json\\nAre you sure you want to continue? (y/N)\\n\\n```\\n 2. Enter y\\n 3. The Pipelines CLI will onboard your pipeline and then provide you a link to set up the proper permissions:\\n[![\\\"Deploy command output with prepared link to bindles website\\\"][13]][13]\\n 4. Open the link in your browser. Confirm the suggested permissions:\\n[![\\\"Bindle UI with set of permissions to be added for Pipeline Actor\\\"][14]][14]\\n\\n7. After a short delay (30+ seconds for larger pipelines), you should see confirmation that the pipeline was edited successfully:\\n[![\\\"Deploy command output with Status: SUCCEEDED\\\"][15]][15]\\n8. Inspect your pipeline, it should now have a new stage called PipelineUpdate with blocked promotions:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline view with PipelineUpdate stage between version set and Packaging stages\\\"][16]][16]\\n9. Confirm that your pipeline looks as expected and Override Active Disables:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline UI component for Active Disables warning\\\"][17]][17]Warning\\nDont re-enable promotions yet! Finish the following steps to push your CDK changes first!\\n10. Create a CR for your CDK changes:\\n\\n```\\ngit commit\\ncr\\n\\n```\\n11. Push your changes once reviewed:\\n\\n```\\ngit push\\n\\n```\\n12. Once your auto-build with CDK changes succeeds, enable a promoti"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-deploy/","displayTitle":"Deploying a pipelines structure","domain":"builder_hub","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1754524800000,"score":0,"rank":5,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"relativeHrefsDescription\":\"Relative hrefs represent related documents that can be accessed by evaluating the relative path with respect to the input URL. Deploying a pipelines structure\\n# Deploying a pipelines structure[][2]\\n* [Deploy a local pipelines structure][3]\\n* [Onboarding a pipeline to use Pipeline Target][4]\\n* [Deploy a pipelines structure from a local file][5]\\n* [See also][6]\\nTo update a pipelines structure from a [Pipeline Structure File][7] and context file, use the `pipelinedeploy` command.\\nThe following sections explain how to use the `pipelinedeploy` command in some common use cases.\\n## Deploy a local pipelines structure[][3]\\nWhen you want to edit your pipeline with local changes, run:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy\\n\\n```\\nAdd the `-F` flag to automatically accept all confirmation dialogs:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -F\\n\\n```\\n## Onboarding a pipeline to use Pipeline Target[][4]\\nUse the `--onboard` option to edit your pipeline with local changes to use the `PipelineUpdate` target ([Pipeline Target mode][8]):\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --onboard\\n\\n```\\nUse the `--onboard` option along with the `-F` flag to edit your pipelines local changes to use the `PipelineUpdate` target and accept all confirmation dialogs:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --onboard -F\\n\\n```\\nUse the `--endpoint=_beta_` flag to deploy a pipelines configuration in the `beta` pipeline partition:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --endpoint=_beta_\\n```\\n## Deploy a pipelines structure from a local file[][5]\\nUse the `-f` flag to provide a specific pipeline structure file for deployment. When you use this flag, you must also use either the `--pipelineName` or `--pipelineId` flags to specify which pipeline to deploy:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -f=_file_ --pipelineName=_name_\\n```\\nOr:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -f=_file_ --pipelineId=_id_\\n```\\nUse `--endpoint=_beta_` flag to deploy pipeline configuration in `beta` pipeline partition:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -f=_file_ --pipelineName=_name_ --endpoint=beta\\n```\\n## See also[][6]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][9]\\n* [Using the pipelines CLI][10]\\n* [pipeline deploy][11]\\nNext page:[Diffing pipeline structures][12]Previous page:[Viewing a pipelines structure][13]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #deploying-a-pipeline-s-structure\\n[3]: #deploy-a-local-pipeline-s-structure\\n[4]: #onboarding-a-pipeline-to-use-pipeline-target\\n[5]: #deploy-a-pipeline-s-structure-from-a-local-file\\n[6]: #see-also\\n[7]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-pipeline-structure-file.html\\n[8]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/concepts-pipeline-config-modes.html#concepts-mode-pipeline-target\\n[9]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-managing-pipeline-via-code.html\\n[10]: ../howto/\\n[11]: ../ref-deploy/\\n[12]: ../howto-diff/\\n[13]: ../howto-view/\"}}"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-configmode/","displayTitle":"Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode","domain":"builder_hub","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1754524800000,"score":0,"rank":6,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"relativeHrefsDescription\":\"Relative hrefs represent related documents that can be accessed by evaluating the relative path with respect to the input URL. Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode\\n# Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode[][2]\\n* [Checking a pipelines configuration mode][3]\\n* [Onboard a pipeline to Pipeline Target configuration mode][4]\\n* [See also][5]\\nTo check the configuration mode of a pipeline, use the `pipelineconfigmode` command.\\nTo execute Pipelines CLI commands against a pipeline, your pipeline **must** be in Pipeline Target mode. For more information about the different configuration modes, see [Pipeline configuration modes][6]\\nNote\\nIn most cases, you shouldnt have to use the `configmode` option directly. The BuilderTools Integrations team primarily uses it for debugging and other tools such as CDKBuild that use it to check if the Pipelines CLI should be invoked or not.\\nFor example, right now running `bbdeploy:pipeline` executes a Pipeline CloudFormation stack deployment. But when `PipelineUpdate` target is used, this deployment doesnt modify your pipelineyou have to use the Pipelines CLI instead.\\nThe following sections explain how to use the `pipelineconfigmode` command in some common use cases.\\n## Checking a pipelines configuration mode[][3]\\nUse the `--pipelineName` flag to specify a pipeline by its name to find out if its configured to use Pipeline Target configuration mode:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineName=_name_\\n```\\nOr, use the `--pipelineId` flag to specify a pipeline by its ID instead:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineId=_id_\\n```\\nAlso, you can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineName=_name_ --json\\n```\\n## Onboard a pipeline to Pipeline Target configuration mode[][4]\\nIn _rare situations_, you may need to update the configuration mode of a pipeline directly.\\nYou can use the `--onboard` flag to do this, while using the `--pipelineName` flag to specify a pipeline by its name:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineName=_name_ --onboard\\n```\\nOr, you can use the `--pipelineId` flag to specify a pipeline by its ID instead:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineId=_id_ --onboard\\n```\\n## See also[][5]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][7]\\n* [Using the pipelines CLI][8]\\n* [pipeline configmode][9]\\nNext page:[CLI reference][10]Previous page:[Diffing pipeline structures][11]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #retrieving-a-pipeline-s-configuration-mode\\n[3]: #checking-a-pipeline-s-configuration-mode\\n[4]: #onboard-a-pipeline-to-pipeline-target-configuration-mode\\n[5]: #see-also\\n[6]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/concepts-pipeline-config-modes.html\\n[7]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-managing-pipeline-via-code.html\\n[8]: ../howto/\\n[9]: ../ref-configmode/\\n[10]: ../reference/\\n[11]: ../howto-diff/\"}}"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-view/","displayTitle":"Viewing a pipelines Viewing a pipelines structure\\n# Viewing a pipelines structure[][2]\\n* [View a local pipelines structure][3]\\n* [View a remote pipelines structure][4]\\n* [View a pipelines structure from a local file][5]\\n* [See also][6]\\nTo view a locally-generated pipelines structure from within a Brazil package, use the `pipelineview` command.\\nThe following sections explain how to use the `pipelineview` command in some common use cases.\\n## View a local pipelines structure[][3]\\nTo view a locally-generated pipelines structure, run the following command:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view\\n\\n```\\nYou can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format as well:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --json\\n\\n```\\nTip\\nRedirect the output of any command to a file for when you need to compare two different pipelines using the [diff option][7]:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --json > myPipeline.txt\\n\\n```\\n## View a remote pipelines structure[][4]\\nUse the `--remote` flag to view the current remote pipelines structure:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote\\n\\n```\\nUse the `--endpoint=_beta_` flag along with the `--remote` flag to view the current remote pipelines structure from the `_beta_` pipeline partition:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote --endpoint=_beta_\\n```\\nAlso, you can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote --endpoint=_beta_ --json\\n```\\nTip\\nRedirect the output of any command to a file for when you need to compare two different pipelines using the [diff option][7]:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote --endpoint=_beta_ --json > myPipeline.txt\\n```\\n## View a pipelines structure from a local file[][5]\\nUse the `-f` flag if you need to read a pipelines structure from specific file:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view -f=_file_\\n```\\nAlso, you can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view -f=_file_ --json\\n```\\n## See also[][6]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][8]\\n* [Using the pipelines CLI][9]\\n* [pipeline view][10]\\nNext page:[Deploying a pipelines structure][11]Previous page:[Using the pipelines CLI][9]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #viewing-a-pipeline-s-structure\\n[3]: #view-a-local-pipeline-s-structure\\n[4]: #view-a-remote-pipeline-s-structure\\n[5]: How to full wash cycle CDK pipeline stacks \\\\(re-bootstrap\\\\)\\n# How to full wash cycle CDK pipeline stacks \\\\(re-bootstrap\\\\)[][2]\\nIf youre experiencing any of the following issues with your Cloud Development Kit (CDK), you may need to full wash cycle (or re-bootstrap) your pipeline:\\n* Youre getting permissions errors when editing or deploying a target, such as:\\n * `S3AccessDenied`\\n * `S3BucketorECRRepoDoesn'tExist`\\n * `ServicePrincipaldoesn'thavepermissionto<some_resource>Resource`\\n\\n* Youre seeing a banner on the Pipelines website that reads This PIPELINE is Administratively STOPPED.\\n* Youve made a change to your pipeline recently and are having other types of issues.\\nFor more information, see [About full wash cycle][3].\\n## How to full wash cycle a CDK pipeline[][4]\\nAll steps use your local code to update your infrastructure and pipeline.\\nNote\\nFor Amazon Dedicated Cloud (ADC) regions, you must also bootstrap your stacks in each ADC account by following these instructions.\\nFollow these steps to full wash cycle your CDK pipeline:\\n1. Ensure youre authenticated using Midway:\\n\\n```\\nmwinit\\n\\n```\\n2. Create a new workspace using your CDK package:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil ws create --root ~/workplace/full-wash-cycle-_my-cdk-package_\\n  --versionset _MyCDKPackageVersionSet_\\n```\\n3. Make a minor change to your CDK package such as editing the pipeline description.\\n4. Build your changes:\\n> \\n> brazil-build release\\n> \\n>\\n5. Create a code review (CR) following your teams normal CR process. **Before merging the CR**, wait for all required approvals and continue the next steps.\\n6. Bootstrap your CDK pipeline:\\nNote\\nIf your pipeline uses the `PipelineUpdate` self mutation stage, please use the commands in the tab `PipelineUpdateTarget` below\\nPipeline Update TargetEnsure the Pipeline definition in your CDK packages `lib/app.ts` is configured with the attribute `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,`\\nWhen performing `brazil-builddeploy:pipeline` you will be asked if you want to continue even though the pipeline shape will not change, choose the yes option.\\n\\n```\\n// Bootstrap Bones resources\\nbrazil-build bootstrap\\n\\n// Deploys BATS Scaffolding and PDG Scaffolding but does not change the pipeline shape\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\nPipeline CFN \\\\(legacy\\\\)\\n```\\n// Bootstrap Bones resources\\nbrazil-build bootstrap\\n\\n```\\n7. Deploy your pipeline:\\nPipeline Update TargetFollow [Getting started][5] document for installing the Pipelines CLI\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy\\n\\n```\\nLegacy Pipeline CFN \\\\(Brazil\\\\)\\n```\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\nThis will also deploy BATS Scaffolding and PDG Scaffolding.\\nLegacy Pipeline CFN \\\\(Peru\\\\)\\n```\\nbrazil-build run amzn-cdk deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\nBe advised that, the exact NPM script may differ, `amzn-cdk` is a general default; make sure to double check your `package.json` in case it is different.\\nThis will also deploy BATS Scaffolding and PDG Scaffolding.\\n8. Merge your CR. You must do this to keep your IaC from getting out of sync with the resources that actually exist.\\nSupport info\\nIf you experience issues with this process, the Pipelines team asks that you do the following **before** requesting their help:\\n1. Capture the output of all commands from this process in a `.txt` file or use `paste.amazon.com`.\\n2. Attach the `.txt` file to or include the `paste.amazon.com` link in a [SIM issue][6]. **Do not paste the output as a comment in the SIM ticket**. If you do, it will most likely truncate and youll be asked for the output again.\\n## Deployment group out of sync with pipeline record[][7]\\nIf you are experiencing an error about the Pipeline Deployment Group (PDG) is out of sync with your pipeline, similar to:\\n\\n```\\nPipeline has detected the deployment group is out of sync with pipeline's record\\n\\n```\\nplease try the following steps:\\n1. Deploy your pipelines by running:\\nPipeline Update Target\\n```\\npipeline deploy\\n\\n```\\nPipeline CFN \\\\(legacy\\\\)\\n```\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\n2. Edit the impacted PDG metadata to force a re-sync.\\nThis is most easily done by adding a new arbitrary tag to the PDG (you can remove this tag after a successful synthesis) or via changing the PDG subtargets (e.g., adding a new subtarget, removing an existing subtarget).\\n## About full wash cycle[][8]\\nThe full wash cycle implements the full code path of your pipelines bootstrapping and Pipeline stage resources (IAM roles, S3 buckets, ECRs, CloudWatch log groups, and KMS keys) to correctly deploy them.\\nDuring this process, CloudFormation checks for pipeline definition changes at the Pipeline stage. If it detects no changes, it wont deploy the stack. To prevent this, youll make a _minor change_ to the Packaging stage (like updating the pipeline description) so the deployment starts with your change already in the version set revision (VSR). Then, youll manually deploy your pipeline before merging in your change.\\nIf you dont make this minor change, CloudFormation wont send the edit to CDK because it bases this check on the CloudFormation database and not the pipelines current status. Thus, trying to deploy the stack, making a manual edit, then manually deploying again wont work because CloudFormation still sees no changes.\\n## See also[][9]\\n* [Troubleshooting][10]\\nNext page:[Reference][11]Previous page:[How to revert PipelineUpdate target onboarding][12]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #how-to-full-wash-cycle-cdk-pipeline-stacks-re-bootstrap\\n[3]: #rebootstrap-cdk-full-wash-cycle-about\\n[4]: #how-to-full-wash-cycle-a-cdk-pipeline\\n[5]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/getting-started.html\\n[6]:
