"mainContent\":\"# Pipelines\\n# Pipelines[][1]\\n* [Stages][2]\\n* [Promotion configurations][3]\\n* [Automation][4]\\n* [Approval workflow][5]\\n* [Deployment Group][6]\\n* [Modeled Change Management][7]\\n_Pipelines_ is a continuous deployment service that you can use to model, visualize, manage, and automate your software release. You can create and manage a pipeline using the web UI or API. This topic provides an overview of important concepts in Pipelines. For more information, see [Pipelines User Guide][8].\\n![][9]Many teams create and manage pipelines using one of the following Infrastructure as Code (IaC) packages:\\n* **CDK package**: The `TypeScript` file in the CDK package includes your pipeline configuration written using a CDK pipeline construct.\\n* **LPT package**: This package includes your pipeline configuration written in a declarative model.\\nA package is built using the **lpt synthesize** command. The build system creates and updates the pipeline according to the declarations, such as stages and approval workflows, in the LPT package template or the `TypeScript` file.\\nAfter you configure the pipeline, you can build, test, and deploy your code changes. A pipeline has the following components:\\n## Stages[][2]\\nPipelines are constructed using a series of stages. A [stage][10] represents a specific step in the release process. Stages in a pipeline vary depending on your teams release infrastructure. However, each pipeline must include the following two stages:\\n* **Packages**: This stage is a collection of packages that you want to build into a version set. The collection of packages typically make up the source code of your application. The dependency packages are not included in this stage.\\n* **Version set**: This stage is your version set revision. It consumes packages through the merge and build promotions. The merge promotion is from the version sets tracking version set. The build promotion is from the Packages stage. Both promotions can be automated to occur when there is a new tracking version set revision or when a code change is merged.\\nThe other stages depend on the type of release and deployment target. For example, if your deployment target is a Prod/Corp Apollo environment, you will have environment stages that align with your Apollo environment. If your deployment target uses Native AWS, your pipeline will include a Packaging stage. In this stage, all the application and runtime dependency build artifacts from the version set revision are transformed and published as artifacts that can be deployed to a Native AWS deployment target.\\n## Promotion configurations[][3]\\nA [Promotion configuration][11] is a connection between two pipeline stages. It includes instructions for how and when the code gets promoted from one stage to another, and whether it can occur automatically.\\n## Automation[][4]\\nPipelines use different agents to automate promotions depending on the connected stages. A pipeline includes the following four primary agents:\\n* **AutoMerge**: The [AutoMerge][12] agent is used to automatically merge your tracking version set to your version set (that is, your Version Set stage). You can schedule an AutoMerge, for example, every 7 days or every time theres a new tracking version set revision.\\n* **AutoBuild**: The [AutoBuild][13] agent is used to automatically create a build request for packages that have been updated after a code merge. AutoBuild watches for new changes in the package branches specified in the Packages stage. If the package in the destination version set is out-of-sync with a source package, a build request is automatically created.\\n* **AutoPromote**: The [AutoPromote][14] agent is used to automatically promote your version set revision to the next stage, for example, to a Packaging stage or a Deployment Group stage. AutoPromote copies the packages in the version set revision to the next stage in the pipeline.\\n* **AutoDeploy**: If your deployment target is Apollo, you can automate deployments using [AutoDeploy][15]. If a destination Apollo environment stage is out-of-sync with its source version set, a deployment is created.\\n## Approval workflow[][5]\\nAn [approval workflow][16] is an automated set of steps that new code revisions must complete before they are promoted to the next stage. For example, your approval workflow may include a step to verify the code changes have an approved review before the AutoBuild agent promotes the changed packages. You may also have a set of integration tests that must be passed before the AutoPromote agent promotes a revision to the next stage.\\nPipelines includes out-of-the-box workflows that you can add to your pipeline anytime. You can also create private workflows to tailor to your teams promotion requirements.\\n## Deployment Group[][6]\\n[Deployment groups][17] enable you to model several deployment targets a"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-pipeline-structure-file/","displayTitle":"Pipeline structure file","domain":"builder_hub","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1754524800000,"score":0,"rank":10,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"relativeHrefsDescription\":\"Relative hrefs represent related documents that can be accessed by evaluating the relative path with respect to the input URL. Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target\\n# Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target[][2]\\n* [Overview][3]\\n* [How PipelineUpdate works][4]\\n * [Limitations][5]\\n\\n* [Permissions][6]\\n* [See also][7]\\n## Overview[][3]\\n`PipelineUpdate` is a [target][8] used by Pipelines as a [configuration mode][9] that allows you to automatically update pipelines using code.\\n[Infrastructure as code][10] is a foundation of region build automation and operational excellence. You may often find yourself adding new resources into your services, which are spread out across many regions and locations. Adding resources using code allows you to create similar environments with large amount of resources, which is close to impossible with manual processes.\\nAdding all these new targets and resources into a pipeline used to be a manual process, until [Live Pipeline Templates (LPT) Synthesis][11] and later [Cloud Development Kit \\\\(CDK\\\\)][12]. Pipeline self-mutation using CloudFormation was the second iteration to automate pipeline management this way. The `PipelineUpdate` target, however, takes the self-mutation concept even further, addressing common issues with CloudFormation-based self-mutation, improving security and the customer experience.\\n## How PipelineUpdate works[][4]\\nThe `PipelineUpdate` target operates as a regular pipeline target, but has some special edge cases:\\n* **During deployments**, the `PipelineUpdate` target downloads build artifacts of configured [Brazil][13] package, parses the generated [pipeline structure file][14], and updates the target pipeline accordingly.\\n* **During manual deployments**, you can edit a pipeline from your dev environment using the [Pipelines CLI][15]. Manual deployments will block your pipeline at the `PipelineUpdate` stage to prevent accidental reversal of your changes. To unblock your pipeline, you must commit and push your code changes first, only then you can enable promotion into the `PipelineUpdate` stage.\\n* **When reverting**, you can revert pipeline structure changes to a previous known state by using Structure History tab. Note that it will create a new deployment into the `PipelineUpdate` target, blocking your pipeline, similarly to the manual deployment just mentioned.\\n### Limitations[][5]\\nThe `PipelineUpdate` target can modify most of the configurable elements of a pipeline, with the following exceptions:\\n* Pipeline name\\n* Pipeline description\\n* Pipeline notification email\\n## Permissions[][6]\\nTo enforce security, pipelines must be allowed to edit or modify resources that are being added via self-mutation. The `PipelineUpdate` target acts as a Pipeline actor in Bindles and requires the same set of permissions as any other actor.\\n`PipelineUpdate` target can update own pipeline or another pipeline. Note, `PipelineUpdate` target doesnt need permissions to edit own pipeline. To edit another pipeline `PipelineUpdate` target must have can edit permissions on that target pipeline.\\nNote\\nWhile we remove the `Pipeline` CloudFormation stack from the pipeline, you can still deploy it using `CDK`. This stack will not have `Pipeline` resource in it, but will have all other resources that you need for BATS.\\n## See also[][7]\\nFor more information about securing your pipelines and managing permissions, see the following:\\n* [How the Brazil CDK pipelines work][16]\\n* [Pipeline structure file][14]\\nNext page:[Pipeline structure file][14]Previous page:[How the Brazil CDK pipelines work][17]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #managing-pipelines-using-code-with-a-pipelineupdate-target\\n[3]: #overview\\n[4]: #how-pipelineupdate-works\\n[5]: #limitations\\n[6]: #permissions\\n[7]: #see-also\\n[8]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/glossary.html#terminology-target\\n[9]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/concepts-pipeline-config-modes.html\\n[10]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/native-aws/developer-guide/concept-infra-as-code.html\\n[11]: /\",\"../reference-re-dashboard/\",\"../reference-metrics/\",\"../reference-release-metrics-causes-issues-actions/\",\"../reference-testing/\",\"../reference-tim-test-case-history/\",\"../reference-tim-test-run-history/\",\"../reference-workflow-step-auto-retry-list/\",\"../troubleshooting/\",\"../troubleshooting-approvals/\",\"../troubleshooting-automation/\",\"../troubleshooting-access-permission-error/\",\"../troubleshooting-pipeline-cfn-stack-status-error-states/\",\"../troubleshooting-ui/\",\"../troubleshooting-promotion-blockers/\",\"../touchless/\",\"../glossary/\",\"../../../../docs/pipelines/cli-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/pipelines/api-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/quilt/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/quilt/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/rde/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/rde/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/region-build-user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/epim-user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/region-build-automation/chain-reaction-user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/smithy/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/smithy/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/sas/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/sas/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/sas/api-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tim/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tim/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tod/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tod/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tps-generator/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/tps-generator/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/transmogrifier/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/transmogrifier/user-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/transmogrifier/api-guide/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/trebuchet/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/universal-constructs/index.html\",\"../../../../docs/universal-constructs/user-guide/index.html Pipeline configuration modes\\n# Pipeline configuration modes[][2]\\n* [Legacy Edit mode][3]\\n* [Pipeline Target mode][4]\\n* [Main differences][5]\\n* [See also][6]\\nYou can manage a pipelines configuration through two distinct modes, which you can see on the Config Mode column in the Structure History tab in [Pipelines][7]:\\n* Legacy Edit - CloudFormation-based method.\\n* Pipeline Target - [PipelineUpdate target][8] method.\\nThis separation allows you to have only one source of edits for a pipeline. Without this configuration, it would be possible to have CloudFormation-based mutation and `PipelineUpdate` mutation in the same pipeline. It would cause a lot of confusion, when your pipeline changes structure several times, depending on what target is deployed. To make things worse, CloudFormation-based solutions dont have the same feature parity with `PipelineUpdate`.\\n## Legacy Edit mode[][3]\\n`LegacyEdit` means your pipeline was mutated by CloudFormation-based solution. When you execute the `bbdeploy:pipeline` command, it will modify your pipeline if CloudFormation Pipeline resource was updated. If `PipelineUpdate` deployments happens, it will fail; pointing to configuration mode incompatibility.\\n## Pipeline Target mode[][4]\\n`PipelineTarget` mode allows the `PipelineUpdate` target to mutate your pipeline. If you directly deploy CloudFormation Pipeline resources, it will fail the deployment; pointing to configuration mode incompatibility.\\n## Main differences[][5]\\n|Use case|Legacy Edit|Pipeline Target|\\n|---|---|---|\\n|CloudFormation Pipeline resource deployment|Will modify pipeline structure if change is present.|Will fail due to configuration mode mismatch.|\\n|`PipelineUpdate` target deployment|Will fail due to configuration mode mismatch.|Will modify pipeline to the configuration described in structure file.|\\n|Deployment effect on manual changes done on pipeline|Deployment will erase manual changes only if there are changes in the generated pipeline structure.|Every deployment will erase manual changes.|\\n|How to deploy changes from local CDK package?|`brazil-builddeploy:pipeline`.|`pipelinedeploy`.|\\n|What `brazil-builddeploy:pipeline` will do?|Create/update necessary scaffolding resources in `Pipeline` stack, modify pipeline via CloudFormation resource.|Create/update necessary scaffolding resources in `Pipeline` stack.|\\n|Permissions model|`AWSAccount` is the main actor that needs permissions.|`Pipeline` is the main actor that needs permissions.|\\n|How to view changes from local CDK package?|`brazil-buildview:pipeline`.|`pipelineview`.|\\n\\n## See also[][6]\\n* [Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode][9]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][8]\\nNext page:[Continuous deployment][10]Previous page:[AutoClone][11]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #pipeline-configuration-modes\\n[3]: #legacy-edit-mode\\n[4]: #pipeline-target-mode\\n[5]: #main-differences\\n[6]: #see-also\\n[7]: https://pipelines.amazon.com/\\n[8]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-managing-pipeline-via-code.html\\n[9]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-configmode.html\\n[10]: How to revert PipelineUpdate target onboarding\\n# How to revert PipelineUpdate target onboarding[][2]\\nFollow these instructions if you decided to convert `PipelineUpdate` target to CloudFormation-based self-mutation.\\n1. [Converting a newly created pipeline from PipelineUpdate to legacy CFN][3]\\n2. [Reverting a pipeline after manual onboarding][4]\\n## Converting a newly created pipeline from PipelineUpdate to legacy CFN[][5]\\n1. In your CDK package, update the legacy pipeline configuration from `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,` to `createLegacyPipelineStage:true,`.\\n2. Offboard your pipeline from `PipelineUpdate` target by running the command:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --offboard --pipelineName=MyPipelineName\\n\\n```\\n3. Synthesize your pipeline using the CDK command:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil-build release\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\n4. Build, commit, get this change reviewed and merged:\\n\\n```\\ngit commit\\ncr\\n\\n```\\n5. Re-enable your pipeline and let CDK changes reach `Pipeline` stage. Enable promotions as needed.\\n## Reverting a pipeline after manual onboarding[][6]\\n### Requirements[][7]\\n1. Make sure your pipeline is using self-mutation via `PipelineUpdate`. It should contain `PipelineUpdate` stage and target similar to this pipeline:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline UI view on the pipeline with PipelineUpdate stage after VersionSet stage\\\"][8]][8]\\n2. Locate your **CDK** package. Usually, it ends with CDK. You will need to revert any code changes associated with initial onboarding.\\n### Revert steps[][9]\\n1. Go to your pipeline page and select `StructureHistory` tab:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline UI structure history view with several entries with different Config Mode values\\\"][10]][10]\\n2. Look at **Config Mode** column, find the latest available record with **Legacy Edit** value in it. This revision will be the one that used CloudFormation-based self-mutation, should contain `Pipeline` stage.\\n3. Use this revision to trigger `Revert`:\\n[![\\\"Single line from StructureHistory view with LegacyEdit value in Config Mode and Revert button\\\"][11]][11]\\n4. After pressing `Revert` you will see additional warning, use `InitiateRevert` button to start the revert:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline Revert UI component with Initiate Revert button\\\"][12]][12]\\n5. Use refresh icon to update the status of the revert:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline Revert UI component with in-progress revert workflow information\\\"][13]][13]\\n6. Once revert is complete, you will see the following:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline Revert UI component with Success status\\\"][14]][14]\\n7. Go to your pipeline, it will be disabled, but `Pipeline` stage will be present again. `PipelineUpdate` will be removed.\\n[![\\\"Pipeline view with blocked pipeline, Pipeline stage after Packaging, PipelineUpdate stage is not present\\\"][15]][15]\\n8. In your CDK package, find a commit that added `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,` configuration. **Revert this commit**.\\n9. Build, commit and get this change reviewed:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil-build\\ngit commit\\ncr\\ngit push\\n\\n```\\n10. Re-enable your pipeline and let CDK changes reach `Pipeline` stage. Enable promotions as needed.\\n11. Once `Pipeline` stage is deployed, revert is complete.\\n[![\\\"Pipeline view with Pipeline stage after Packaging, everything is enabled\\\"][16]][16]\\n## Troubleshooting[][17]\\nWe dont have any known problems yet, tell us if you find something.\\n### Something else[][18]\\nIn case you encounter an issue, that is not listed here, let us know by creating a SIM using this [template][19]..\\nNext page:[How to full wash cycle CDK pipeline stacks \\\\(re-bootstrap\\\\)][20]Previous page:[Onboarding CDK pipelines to PipelineUpdate][21]\\n[1]: oing-promotion.png\",\"../_images/pipeline-using-pipeline-target.png\",\"../howto-revert-pipelineupdate-migration/\",\"../howto-revert-pipelineupdate-migration/\",\"../howto-revert-pipelineupdate-migration/\",\"../howto-cdk-upgrade-constructs/\"],\"mainContent\":\"![][1]# Onboarding CDK pipelines to PipelineUpdate\\n# Onboarding CDK pipelines to PipelineUpdate[][2]\\nThese instructions cover requirements and steps to migrate an existing Cloud Development Kit (CDK) Pipeline from a CloudFormation-based self-mutation to a [PipelineUpdate target][3].\\n## Prerequisites[][4]\\n1. Make sure your pipeline is using self-mutation using CloudFormation. First stages of your pipeline should look similar to this pipeline. It should have Packaging and Pipeline stages.\\n[![\\\"Pipeline with Pipeline stage after Packaging stage\\\"][5]][5]\\n2. Locate your CDK package. Usually, it ends with CDK. Make sure you are using the latest version of [PipelinesConstructs][6], `\\\"version\\\"` should be at least `4.0.123`. If you are using NodeJS, run:\\n\\n```\\nnpm explain @amzn/pipelines\\n\\n```\\nNote\\nYou may need to use `brazil-buildappexplain@amzn/pipelines` if you dont have `npm` installed.\\nExample output that you may see:\\n\\n```\\n@amzn/pipelines@4.0.106\\nnode_modules/@amzn/pipelines\\n @amzn/pipelines@\\\"^4.0.8\\\" from the root project\\n peer @amzn/pipelines@\\\"^4.0.79\\\" from @amzn/hydra@4.0.24\\n node_modules/@amzn/hydra\\n @amzn/hydra@\\\"^4.0.1\\\" from the root project\\n\\n```\\n3. Make sure there are no additional targets in your Pipeline stage. While onboarding, the Pipeline stage is not created and if you have custom targets in this stage, the CDK build will fail. Follow troubleshooting [Custom targets in the Pipeline stage][7].\\n4. Pipelines CLI is installed. Follow [Getting started][8] for the installation instructions.\\n## Onboard a CDK pipeline to PipelineUpdate[][9]\\n1. In your CDK package, update `PipelineDeployment` by adding additional configuration: add `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,` configuration. This configuration will tell CDK to not create `Pipeline` stage.\\n[![\\\"Example code change with 'createLegacyPipelineStage: false' in DeploymentPipeline\\\"][10]][10]\\n2. Build your CDK changes:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil-build\\n\\n```\\nNote\\nIf your build failed, see [Troubleshooting][11].\\n3. Use the `pipelinediff` command to validate the expected changes:\\n\\n```\\npipeline diff\\n\\n```\\n4. Pipelines CLI output may look something like this (exact report structure is subject to change):\\n[![\\\"Diff command output with added selfMutation stage, removed Pipeline stage\\\"][12]][12]\\n5. Confirm that your Pipeline stage is being removed as well as corresponding Pipeline Deployment Group (PDG). At the same time, add the `selfMutationStage`.\\nNote\\nWhile we remove `Pipeline` CloudFormation stack from the pipeline, you can still deploy it using `cdk`. This stack will not have `Pipeline` resource in it, but will have all other resources that you need for BATS.\\n6. Onboard your pipeline to `PipelineUpdate` target by deploying your new pipeline structure:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --onboard\\n\\n```\\n 1. The Pipelines CLI will ask you to confirm your changes, for example:\\n\\n```\\nYou are about to modify pipeline:\\n* Name: PipelineTargetOnboardingDemo\\n* ID: 6359169\\n* Source file path: build/pipeline-structure/Pipeline.json\\nAre you sure you want to continue? (y/N)\\n\\n```\\n 2. Enter y\\n 3. The Pipelines CLI will onboard your pipeline and then provide you a link to set up the proper permissions:\\n[![\\\"Deploy command output with prepared link to bindles website\\\"][13]][13]\\n 4. Open the link in your browser. Confirm the suggested permissions:\\n[![\\\"Bindle UI with set of permissions to be added for Pipeline Actor\\\"][14]][14]\\n\\n7. After a short delay (30+ seconds for larger pipelines), you should see confirmation that the pipeline was edited successfully:\\n[![\\\"Deploy command output with Status: SUCCEEDED\\\"][15]][15]\\n8. Inspect your pipeline, it should now have a new stage called PipelineUpdate with blocked promotions:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline view with PipelineUpdate stage between version set and Packaging stages\\\"][16]][16]\\n9. Confirm that your pipeline looks as expected and Override Active Disables:\\n[![\\\"Pipeline UI component for Active Disables warning\\\"][17]][17]Warning\\nDont re-enable promotions yet! Finish the following steps to push your CDK changes first!\\n10. Create a CR for your CDK changes:\\n\\n```\\ngit commit\\ncr\\n\\n```\\n11. Push your changes once reviewed:\\n\\n```\\ngit push\\n\\n```\\n12. Once your auto-build with CDK changes succeeds, enable a promoti"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-deploy/","displayTitle":"Deploying a pipelines structure","domain":"builder_hub","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1754524800000,"score":0,"rank":5,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"relativeHrefsDescription\":\"Relative hrefs represent related documents that can be accessed by evaluating the relative path with respect to the input URL. Deploying a pipelines structure\\n# Deploying a pipelines structure[][2]\\n* [Deploy a local pipelines structure][3]\\n* [Onboarding a pipeline to use Pipeline Target][4]\\n* [Deploy a pipelines structure from a local file][5]\\n* [See also][6]\\nTo update a pipelines structure from a [Pipeline Structure File][7] and context file, use the `pipelinedeploy` command.\\nThe following sections explain how to use the `pipelinedeploy` command in some common use cases.\\n## Deploy a local pipelines structure[][3]\\nWhen you want to edit your pipeline with local changes, run:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy\\n\\n```\\nAdd the `-F` flag to automatically accept all confirmation dialogs:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -F\\n\\n```\\n## Onboarding a pipeline to use Pipeline Target[][4]\\nUse the `--onboard` option to edit your pipeline with local changes to use the `PipelineUpdate` target ([Pipeline Target mode][8]):\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --onboard\\n\\n```\\nUse the `--onboard` option along with the `-F` flag to edit your pipelines local changes to use the `PipelineUpdate` target and accept all confirmation dialogs:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --onboard -F\\n\\n```\\nUse the `--endpoint=_beta_` flag to deploy a pipelines configuration in the `beta` pipeline partition:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy --endpoint=_beta_\\n```\\n## Deploy a pipelines structure from a local file[][5]\\nUse the `-f` flag to provide a specific pipeline structure file for deployment. When you use this flag, you must also use either the `--pipelineName` or `--pipelineId` flags to specify which pipeline to deploy:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -f=_file_ --pipelineName=_name_\\n```\\nOr:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -f=_file_ --pipelineId=_id_\\n```\\nUse `--endpoint=_beta_` flag to deploy pipeline configuration in `beta` pipeline partition:\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy -f=_file_ --pipelineName=_name_ --endpoint=beta\\n```\\n## See also[][6]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][9]\\n* [Using the pipelines CLI][10]\\n* [pipeline deploy][11]\\nNext page:[Diffing pipeline structures][12]Previous page:[Viewing a pipelines structure][13]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #deploying-a-pipeline-s-structure\\n[3]: #deploy-a-local-pipeline-s-structure\\n[4]: #onboarding-a-pipeline-to-use-pipeline-target\\n[5]: #deploy-a-pipeline-s-structure-from-a-local-file\\n[6]: #see-also\\n[7]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-pipeline-structure-file.html\\n[8]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/concepts-pipeline-config-modes.html#concepts-mode-pipeline-target\\n[9]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-managing-pipeline-via-code.html\\n[10]: ../howto/\\n[11]: ../ref-deploy/\\n[12]: ../howto-diff/\\n[13]: ../howto-view/\"}}"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-configmode/","displayTitle":"Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode","domain":"builder_hub","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1754524800000,"score":0,"rank":6,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"relativeHrefsDescription\":\"Relative hrefs represent related documents that can be accessed by evaluating the relative path with respect to the input URL. Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode\\n# Retrieving a pipelines configuration mode[][2]\\n* [Checking a pipelines configuration mode][3]\\n* [Onboard a pipeline to Pipeline Target configuration mode][4]\\n* [See also][5]\\nTo check the configuration mode of a pipeline, use the `pipelineconfigmode` command.\\nTo execute Pipelines CLI commands against a pipeline, your pipeline **must** be in Pipeline Target mode. For more information about the different configuration modes, see [Pipeline configuration modes][6]\\nNote\\nIn most cases, you shouldnt have to use the `configmode` option directly. The BuilderTools Integrations team primarily uses it for debugging and other tools such as CDKBuild that use it to check if the Pipelines CLI should be invoked or not.\\nFor example, right now running `bbdeploy:pipeline` executes a Pipeline CloudFormation stack deployment. But when `PipelineUpdate` target is used, this deployment doesnt modify your pipelineyou have to use the Pipelines CLI instead.\\nThe following sections explain how to use the `pipelineconfigmode` command in some common use cases.\\n## Checking a pipelines configuration mode[][3]\\nUse the `--pipelineName` flag to specify a pipeline by its name to find out if its configured to use Pipeline Target configuration mode:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineName=_name_\\n```\\nOr, use the `--pipelineId` flag to specify a pipeline by its ID instead:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineId=_id_\\n```\\nAlso, you can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineName=_name_ --json\\n```\\n## Onboard a pipeline to Pipeline Target configuration mode[][4]\\nIn _rare situations_, you may need to update the configuration mode of a pipeline directly.\\nYou can use the `--onboard` flag to do this, while using the `--pipelineName` flag to specify a pipeline by its name:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineName=_name_ --onboard\\n```\\nOr, you can use the `--pipelineId` flag to specify a pipeline by its ID instead:\\n\\n```\\npipeline configmode --pipelineId=_id_ --onboard\\n```\\n## See also[][5]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][7]\\n* [Using the pipelines CLI][8]\\n* [pipeline configmode][9]\\nNext page:[CLI reference][10]Previous page:[Diffing pipeline structures][11]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #retrieving-a-pipeline-s-configuration-mode\\n[3]: #checking-a-pipeline-s-configuration-mode\\n[4]: #onboard-a-pipeline-to-pipeline-target-configuration-mode\\n[5]: #see-also\\n[6]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/user-guide/concepts-pipeline-config-modes.html\\n[7]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-managing-pipeline-via-code.html\\n[8]: ../howto/\\n[9]: ../ref-configmode/\\n[10]: ../reference/\\n[11]: ../howto-diff/\"}}"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/howto-view/","displayTitle":"Viewing a pipelines Viewing a pipelines structure\\n# Viewing a pipelines structure[][2]\\n* [View a local pipelines structure][3]\\n* [View a remote pipelines structure][4]\\n* [View a pipelines structure from a local file][5]\\n* [See also][6]\\nTo view a locally-generated pipelines structure from within a Brazil package, use the `pipelineview` command.\\nThe following sections explain how to use the `pipelineview` command in some common use cases.\\n## View a local pipelines structure[][3]\\nTo view a locally-generated pipelines structure, run the following command:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view\\n\\n```\\nYou can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format as well:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --json\\n\\n```\\nTip\\nRedirect the output of any command to a file for when you need to compare two different pipelines using the [diff option][7]:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --json > myPipeline.txt\\n\\n```\\n## View a remote pipelines structure[][4]\\nUse the `--remote` flag to view the current remote pipelines structure:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote\\n\\n```\\nUse the `--endpoint=_beta_` flag along with the `--remote` flag to view the current remote pipelines structure from the `_beta_` pipeline partition:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote --endpoint=_beta_\\n```\\nAlso, you can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote --endpoint=_beta_ --json\\n```\\nTip\\nRedirect the output of any command to a file for when you need to compare two different pipelines using the [diff option][7]:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view --remote --endpoint=_beta_ --json > myPipeline.txt\\n```\\n## View a pipelines structure from a local file[][5]\\nUse the `-f` flag if you need to read a pipelines structure from specific file:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view -f=_file_\\n```\\nAlso, you can use the `--json` flag to output the command in JSON format:\\n\\n```\\npipeline view -f=_file_ --json\\n```\\n## See also[][6]\\n* [Managing pipelines using code with a PipelineUpdate target][8]\\n* [Using the pipelines CLI][9]\\n* [pipeline view][10]\\nNext page:[Deploying a pipelines structure][11]Previous page:[Using the pipelines CLI][9]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #viewing-a-pipeline-s-structure\\n[3]: #view-a-local-pipeline-s-structure\\n[4]: #view-a-remote-pipeline-s-structure\\n[5]: How to full wash cycle CDK pipeline stacks \\\\(re-bootstrap\\\\)\\n# How to full wash cycle CDK pipeline stacks \\\\(re-bootstrap\\\\)[][2]\\nIf youre experiencing any of the following issues with your Cloud Development Kit (CDK), you may need to full wash cycle (or re-bootstrap) your pipeline:\\n* Youre getting permissions errors when editing or deploying a target, such as:\\n * `S3AccessDenied`\\n * `S3BucketorECRRepoDoesn'tExist`\\n * `ServicePrincipaldoesn'thavepermissionto<some_resource>Resource`\\n\\n* Youre seeing a banner on the Pipelines website that reads This PIPELINE is Administratively STOPPED.\\n* Youve made a change to your pipeline recently and are having other types of issues.\\nFor more information, see [About full wash cycle][3].\\n## How to full wash cycle a CDK pipeline[][4]\\nAll steps use your local code to update your infrastructure and pipeline.\\nNote\\nFor Amazon Dedicated Cloud (ADC) regions, you must also bootstrap your stacks in each ADC account by following these instructions.\\nFollow these steps to full wash cycle your CDK pipeline:\\n1. Ensure youre authenticated using Midway:\\n\\n```\\nmwinit\\n\\n```\\n2. Create a new workspace using your CDK package:\\n\\n```\\nbrazil ws create --root ~/workplace/full-wash-cycle-_my-cdk-package_\\n  --versionset _MyCDKPackageVersionSet_\\n```\\n3. Make a minor change to your CDK package such as editing the pipeline description.\\n4. Build your changes:\\n> \\n> brazil-build release\\n> \\n>\\n5. Create a code review (CR) following your teams normal CR process. **Before merging the CR**, wait for all required approvals and continue the next steps.\\n6. Bootstrap your CDK pipeline:\\nNote\\nIf your pipeline uses the `PipelineUpdate` self mutation stage, please use the commands in the tab `PipelineUpdateTarget` below\\nPipeline Update TargetEnsure the Pipeline definition in your CDK packages `lib/app.ts` is configured with the attribute `createLegacyPipelineStage:false,`\\nWhen performing `brazil-builddeploy:pipeline` you will be asked if you want to continue even though the pipeline shape will not change, choose the yes option.\\n\\n```\\n// Bootstrap Bones resources\\nbrazil-build bootstrap\\n\\n// Deploys BATS Scaffolding and PDG Scaffolding but does not change the pipeline shape\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\nPipeline CFN \\\\(legacy\\\\)\\n```\\n// Bootstrap Bones resources\\nbrazil-build bootstrap\\n\\n```\\n7. Deploy your pipeline:\\nPipeline Update TargetFollow [Getting started][5] document for installing the Pipelines CLI\\n\\n```\\npipeline deploy\\n\\n```\\nLegacy Pipeline CFN \\\\(Brazil\\\\)\\n```\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\nThis will also deploy BATS Scaffolding and PDG Scaffolding.\\nLegacy Pipeline CFN \\\\(Peru\\\\)\\n```\\nbrazil-build run amzn-cdk deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\nBe advised that, the exact NPM script may differ, `amzn-cdk` is a general default; make sure to double check your `package.json` in case it is different.\\nThis will also deploy BATS Scaffolding and PDG Scaffolding.\\n8. Merge your CR. You must do this to keep your IaC from getting out of sync with the resources that actually exist.\\nSupport info\\nIf you experience issues with this process, the Pipelines team asks that you do the following **before** requesting their help:\\n1. Capture the output of all commands from this process in a `.txt` file or use `paste.amazon.com`.\\n2. Attach the `.txt` file to or include the `paste.amazon.com` link in a [SIM issue][6]. **Do not paste the output as a comment in the SIM ticket**. If you do, it will most likely truncate and youll be asked for the output again.\\n## Deployment group out of sync with pipeline record[][7]\\nIf you are experiencing an error about the Pipeline Deployment Group (PDG) is out of sync with your pipeline, similar to:\\n\\n```\\nPipeline has detected the deployment group is out of sync with pipeline's record\\n\\n```\\nplease try the following steps:\\n1. Deploy your pipelines by running:\\nPipeline Update Target\\n```\\npipeline deploy\\n\\n```\\nPipeline CFN \\\\(legacy\\\\)\\n```\\nbrazil-build deploy:pipeline\\n\\n```\\n2. Edit the impacted PDG metadata to force a re-sync.\\nThis is most easily done by adding a new arbitrary tag to the PDG (you can remove this tag after a successful synthesis) or via changing the PDG subtargets (e.g., adding a new subtarget, removing an existing subtarget).\\n## About full wash cycle[][8]\\nThe full wash cycle implements the full code path of your pipelines bootstrapping and Pipeline stage resources (IAM roles, S3 buckets, ECRs, CloudWatch log groups, and KMS keys) to correctly deploy them.\\nDuring this process, CloudFormation checks for pipeline definition changes at the Pipeline stage. If it detects no changes, it wont deploy the stack. To prevent this, youll make a _minor change_ to the Packaging stage (like updating the pipeline description) so the deployment starts with your change already in the version set revision (VSR). Then, youll manually deploy your pipeline before merging in your change.\\nIf you dont make this minor change, CloudFormation wont send the edit to CDK because it bases this check on the CloudFormation database and not the pipelines current status. Thus, trying to deploy the stack, making a manual edit, then manually deploying again wont work because CloudFormation still sees no changes.\\n## See also[][9]\\n* [Troubleshooting][10]\\nNext page:[Reference][11]Previous page:[How to revert PipelineUpdate target onboarding][12]\\n[1]: ../pipelines-logo-48px.png\\n[2]: #how-to-full-wash-cycle-cdk-pipeline-stacks-re-bootstrap\\n[3]: #rebootstrap-cdk-full-wash-cycle-about\\n[4]: #how-to-full-wash-cycle-a-cdk-pipeline\\n[5]: https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cli-guide/getting-started.html\\n[6]: "mainContent\":\"# Pipelines\\n# Pipelines[][1]\\n* [Stages][2]\\n* [Promotion configurations][3]\\n* [Automation][4]\\n* [Approval workflow][5]\\n* [Deployment Group][6]\\n* [Modeled Change Management][7]\\n_Pipelines_ is a continuous deployment service that you can use to model, visualize, manage, and automate your software release. You can create and manage a pipeline using the web UI or API. This topic provides an overview of important concepts in Pipelines. For more information, see [Pipelines User Guide][8].\\n![][9]Many teams create and manage pipelines using one of the following Infrastructure as Code (IaC) packages:\\n* **CDK package**: The `TypeScript` file in the CDK package includes your pipeline configuration written using a CDK pipeline construct.\\n* **LPT package**: This package includes your pipeline configuration written in a declarative model.\\nA package is built using the **lpt synthesize** command. The build system creates and updates the pipeline according to the declarations, such as stages and approval workflows, in the LPT package template or the `TypeScript` file.\\nAfter you configure the pipeline, you can build, test, and deploy your code changes. A pipeline has the following components:\\n## Stages[][2]\\nPipelines are constructed using a series of stages. A [stage][10] represents a specific step in the release process. Stages in a pipeline vary depending on your teams release infrastructure. However, each pipeline must include the following two stages:\\n* **Packages**: This stage is a collection of packages that you want to build into a version set. The collection of packages typically make up the source code of your application. The dependency packages are not included in this stage.\\n* **Version set**: This stage is your version set revision. It consumes packages through the merge and build promotions. The merge promotion is from the version sets tracking version set. The build promotion is from the Packages stage. Both promotions can be automated to occur when there is a new tracking version set revision or when a code change is merged.\\nThe other stages depend on the type of release and deployment target. For example, if your deployment target is a Prod/Corp Apollo environment, you will have environment stages that align with your Apollo environment. If your deployment target uses Native AWS, your pipeline will include a Packaging stage. In this stage, all the application and runtime dependency build artifacts from the version set revision are transformed and published as artifacts that can be deployed to a Native AWS deployment target.\\n## Promotion configurations[][3]\\nA [Promotion configuration][11] is a connection between two pipeline stages. It includes instructions for how and when the code gets promoted from one stage to another, and whether it can occur automatically.\\n## Automation[][4]\\nPipelines use different agents to automate promotions depending on the connected stages. A pipeline includes the following four primary agents:\\n* **AutoMerge**: The [AutoMerge][12] agent is used to automatically merge your tracking version set to your version set (that is, your Version Set stage). You can schedule an AutoMerge, for example, every 7 days or every time theres a new tracking version set revision.\\n* **AutoBuild**: The [AutoBuild][13] agent is used to automatically create a build request for packages that have been updated after a code merge. AutoBuild watches for new changes in the package branches specified in the Packages stage. If the package in the destination version set is out-of-sync with a source package, a build request is automatically created.\\n* **AutoPromote**: The [AutoPromote][14] agent is used to automatically promote your version set revision to the next stage, for example, to a Packaging stage or a Deployment Group stage. AutoPromote copies the packages in the version set revision to the next stage in the pipeline.\\n* **AutoDeploy**: If your deployment target is Apollo, you can automate deployments using [AutoDeploy][15]. If a destination Apollo environment stage is out-of-sync with its source version set, a deployment is created.\\n## Approval workflow[][5]\\nAn [approval workflow][16] is an automated set of steps that new code revisions must complete before they are promoted to the next stage. For example, your approval workflow may include a step to verify the code changes have an approved review before the AutoBuild agent promotes the changed packages. You may also have a set of integration tests that must be passed before the AutoPromote agent promotes a revision to the next stage.\\nPipelines includes out-of-the-box workflows that you can add to your pipeline anytime. You can also create private workflows to tailor to your teams promotion requirements.\\n## Deployment Group[][6]\\n[Deployment groups][17] enable you to model several deployment targets a"},{"url":"https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/pipelines/cdk-guide/concepts-pipeline-structure-file/","displayTitle":"Pipeline structure file","domain":"builder_hub","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1754524800000,"score":0,"rank":10,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"relativeHrefsDescription\":\"Relative hrefs represent related documents that can be accessed by evaluating the relative path with respect to the input URL. input.description: Create PipelineUpdate Target golden path doc
input.prompt:
Create a comprehensive golden path recommendation document for using PipelineUpdate Target in Amazon Pipelines. This should be a BuilderHub documentation file in reStructuredText format following Amazon's BuilderHub style guide.

Based on the following information about PipelineUpdate Target:
- PipelineUpdate is a target that allows automatic pipeline updates using code (Infrastructure as Code)
- It operates as a regular pipeline target with special capabilities for self-mutation
- During deployments, it downloads build artifacts, parses the pipeline structure file, and updates the pipeline
- It's more secure and provides better customer experience than CloudFormation-based self-mutation
- Requires proper permissions through Bindles for security
- Can modify most pipeline elements except: pipeline name, description, and notification email
- Uses Pipeline Target configuration mode vs Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode
- Migration involves adding createLegacyPipelineStage:false to CDK configuration
- Uses the Pipelines CLI commands: pipeline deploy, pipeline diff, pipeline view

The document should:
1. Follow BuilderHub documentation standards for web_services directory (golden-path pattern)
2. Include proper RST formatting with copyright header, contribution links
3. Use reference pattern: golden-path-pipelineupdate-target
4. Include sections: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, When to use, Migration guide
5. Use second person voice, active voice, sentence case headings
6. Include cross-references to related AWS services and documentation
7. Use :awsdocs: roles for AWS documentation links
8. Keep line length ~100 characters
9. Include practical code examples
10. Address common use cases and troubleshooting

Create a complete, production-ready golden path recommendation document that teams can use to adopt PipelineUpdate Target for managing their pipelines as code.

Create a comprehensive golden path recommendation document for using PipelineUpdate Target in Amazon Pipelines. This should be a BuilderHub documentation file in reStructuredText format following Amazon's BuilderHub style guide.

Based on the following information about PipelineUpdate Target:
- PipelineUpdate is a target that allows automatic pipeline updates using code (Infrastructure as Code)
- It operates as a regular pipeline target with special capabilities for self-mutation
- During deployments, it downloads build artifacts, parses the pipeline structure file, and updates the pipeline
- It's more secure and provides better customer experience than CloudFormation-based self-mutation
- Requires proper permissions through Bindles for security
- Can modify most pipeline elements except: pipeline name, description, and notification email
- Uses Pipeline Target configuration mode vs Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode
- Migration involves adding createLegacyPipelineStage:false to CDK configuration
- Uses the Pipelines CLI commands: pipeline deploy, pipeline diff, pipeline view

The document should:

2. Include proper RST formatting with copyright header, contribution links
3. Use reference pattern: golden-path-pipelineupdate-target
4. Include sections: Recommendation, Best practices, Caveats, When to use, Migration guide

    24.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_cdk:
    25
    26Use AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK)
    27-----------------------------------
    28
    29AWS CDK is a framework to model and provision AWS resources and internal resources
    30using familiar programming languages. Unlike legacy CfnBuild-based applications, which build a
    31single CloudFormation template per stack for deployment through a pipeline, CDK produces one
    32CloudFormation template per deployment target in a pipeline.
    33
    34When using the CDK, avoid using **AWS CloudFormation-only** (L1) constructs where possible. Use
    35**Curated** (L2) constructs instead. Use **Pattern** (L3) constructs only when you are certain you
    36do not need to customize the underlying resources. Pattern constructs couple the fate of the
    37resources they create. The ``NetworkLoadBalancedFargateService`` construct, for example, implies
    38an abstraction when none actually exists; the construct automates the configuration of both an NLB
    39and Fargate service, but you still own the fundamental resources. The pattern construct may also
    40be opinionated in its configuration in a way that does not apply to your service. Alternatively,
    41the ``DeploymentPipeline`` pattern construct configures an internal Pipeline and may be an
    42acceptable tradeoff between automation and resource coupling. See
    43:awsdocs:`CDK key concepts <cdk/latest/guide/getting_started.html#getting_started_concepts>`
    44for more information about the three fundamental flavors of CDK constructs.

    51Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps
    52required to release your software. It picks up the CloudFormation templates generated from your CDK
    53application, and deploys them to the destinations configured in your pipeline definition.

    55Your pipeline definition is also managed by CDK using the `@amzn/pipelines`_ package.
    56Behind the scene, the pipeline definition is presented as a :wiki:`self-service CloudFormation resource <AWS21/Self_Service/>`.
    57|bhub-create|_ provides a number of options to create applications with pipelines managed by the CDK.

.. Copyright  2023, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

#######################################
Golden Path - infrastructure management
#######################################

.. meta::
   :description: Golden Path - Infrastructure management

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendations
===============

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_cdk:

Use AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK)
-----------------------------------

AWS CDK is a framework to model and provision AWS resources and internal resources
using familiar programming languages. Unlike legacy CfnBuild-based applications, which build a
single CloudFormation template per stack for deployment through a pipeline, CDK produces one
CloudFormation template per deployment target in a pipeline.

When using the CDK, avoid using **AWS CloudFormation-only** (L1) constructs where possible. Use
**Curated** (L2) constructs instead. Use **Pattern** (L3) constructs only when you are certain you
do not need to customize the underlying resources. Pattern constructs couple the fate of the
resources they create. The ``NetworkLoadBalancedFargateService`` construct, for example, implies
an abstraction when none actually exists; the construct automates the configuration of both an NLB
and Fargate service, but you still own the fundamental resources. The pattern construct may also
be opinionated in its configuration in a way that does not apply to your service. Alternatively,
the ``DeploymentPipeline`` pattern construct configures an internal Pipeline and may be an
acceptable tradeoff between automation and resource coupling. See
:awsdocs:`CDK key concepts <cdk/latest/guide/getting_started.html#getting_started_concepts>`
for more information about the three fundamental flavors of CDK constructs.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_pipelines:

Automate your infrastructure deployment with Pipelines
------------------------------------------------------

Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps
required to release your software. It picks up the CloudFormation templates generated from your CDK
application, and deploys them to the destinations configured in your pipeline definition.

Your pipeline definition is also managed by CDK using the `@amzn/pipelines`_ package.
Behind the scene, the pipeline definition is presented as a :wiki:`self-service CloudFormation resource <AWS21/Self_Service/>`.
|bhub-create|_ provides a number of options to create applications with pipelines managed by the CDK.

.. _`@amzn/pipelines`: https://devcentral.amazon.com/ac/brazil/package-master/package/go/?flavor=private&path=typedoc/index.html&name=PipelinesConstructs&interface=4.0.0&versionSet=AmznPipelinesConstructs/development&platform=AL2_x86_64


How-tos
=======

* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-lambda-cdk`.
* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-ecs`.

Caveats
=======


Feature parity with LPT
-----------------------

Although the CDK can be seen as the replacement of :doc:`Live Pipeline Templates (LPT) <lptug:index>`
as a tool to manage your infrastructure, some resources are still not available via officially supported
CDK constructs. Teams that vend internal resources must onboard with
:wiki:`Uluru <AWS21/Design/Uluru>` for CloudFormation in order to make the resources available in
the CDK.

The workaround is to use LPT to manage resources that are yet to be supported by CDK. Migrate to the
CDK as soon as the resources are supported. Refer to the :doc:`LPT user guide <lptug:getting-started>`
to get started with LPT.


MoteCDK language support
------------------------

:wiki:`Mote <Infosec/CloudSecurity/SecureDefaults/MoteCDK/>` only supports
TypeScript. You must use TypeScript for your CDK application if you need to
use Mote.


Non-recommended options
=======================

Raw CloudFormation templates
----------------------------

Raw CloudFormation templates are based on markup languages (YAML or JSON), not real programming

    20
    21Recommendations
    22===============
    23
    24.. _golden_path_recommendation_cloudformation_stack_management_prefer_sibling_stacks:
    25
    26Prefer sibling stacks over nested stacks
    27----------------------------------------
    28
    29When the number of resources in your CloudFormation stack is approaching the service quota, you will
    30want to create new resources in a different stack. You have two options for the new stack: a nested
    31stack or a sibling stack.
    32
    33* *A nested stack* is a CloudFormation stack that is created as part of another stack. You create
    34  a nested stack within another stack by using the
    35  :awsdocs:`AWS::CloudFormation::Stack <AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-stack.html>`

    39  can :awsdocs:`reference resources <cdk/v2/guide/resources.html#resource_stack>` from a sibling
    40  stack in another stack. It is not a child of any stack and is deployed independently from other
    41  sibling stacks.
    42

    44You can use two common frameworks to decide which resources should go in each stack: the
    45multi-layered architecture and the service-oriented architecture (SOA) (see
    46:awsdocs:`the guidance for organizing your stacks by lifecycle and ownership
    47<AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html#organizingstacks>`). Using multiple sibling
    48stacks allows your stacks to be deployed independently and minimize blast radius. You should only use
    49nested stacks when your resources are tightly coupled and you prefer them to be deployed and
    50rolled-back as a single operation.
    51
    52
    53Caveats
    54=======
    55
    56Nested stack's lack of internal support

    60  Pipelines interface).

#############################################
Golden Path - CloudFormation stack management
#############################################

.. meta::
   :description: Golden Path - CloudFormation Stack Management

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendations
===============

.. _golden_path_recommendation_cloudformation_stack_management_prefer_sibling_stacks:

Prefer sibling stacks over nested stacks
----------------------------------------

When the number of resources in your CloudFormation stack is approaching the service quota, you will
want to create new resources in a different stack. You have two options for the new stack: a nested
stack or a sibling stack.

* *A nested stack* is a CloudFormation stack that is created as part of another stack. You create
  a nested stack within another stack by using the
  :awsdocs:`AWS::CloudFormation::Stack <AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-stack.html>`
  CloudFormation resource or the :awsdocs:`NestedStack construct <cdk/api/v1/docs/@aws-cdk_core.NestedStack.html>`.
  A nested stack is not independently deployed: it needs to be deployed together with its parent.
* *A sibling stack* is a normal CloudFormation stack where you put additional resources, and you
  can :awsdocs:`reference resources <cdk/v2/guide/resources.html#resource_stack>` from a sibling
  stack in another stack. It is not a child of any stack and is deployed independently from other
  sibling stacks.

In general, you should split your resources into multiple sibling stacks based on their lifecycle.
You can use two common frameworks to decide which resources should go in each stack: the
multi-layered architecture and the service-oriented architecture (SOA) (see
:awsdocs:`the guidance for organizing your stacks by lifecycle and ownership
<AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html#organizingstacks>`). Using multiple sibling
stacks allows your stacks to be deployed independently and minimize blast radius. You should only use
nested stacks when your resources are tightly coupled and you prefer them to be deployed and
rolled-back as a single operation.


Caveats
=======

Nested stack's lack of internal support
---------------------------------------

* Pipelines does not track a nested stack's deployment progress (i.e., they are not visible in the
  Pipelines interface).

* The :guilabel:`ChangeSetApproval` workflow does not support nested stack change sets (i.e.,
  you cannot see which resources are being updated when approving a change set).

* :doc:`Change Guardian <changeguardian:index>` does not analyze nested stack as they are not part of the
  Pipeline definition (:sim:`NT-1605`).

You cannot update the value of a cross-stack reference
------------------------------------------------------

When establishing a cross-stack reference between two sibling stacks, you export a resource from a
stack so that other stacks can use them with the ``Fn::ImportValue`` function. Once the value
has been imported, you can no longer update it nor delete the export. In order to work around this
issue, you need a 2-step deployment to:

#. Remove or replace the ``Fn::ImportValue`` usage with a hard-coded value.
#. Update the referenced value and switch back to use the ``Fn::ImportValue`` function.

.. Copyright  2025, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:

##################################################
Golden Path - PipelineUpdate Target for Pipelines
##################################################

.. meta::
   :description: Golden Path - PipelineUpdate Target for managing pipelines as code

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendations
===============

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_target:

Use PipelineUpdate Target for pipeline self-mutation
----------------------------------------------------

PipelineUpdate Target is a specialized pipeline target that enables automatic pipeline updates using
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) principles. It allows your pipeline to update itself by downloading
build artifacts, parsing the pipeline structure file, and applying changes during deployments.

Unlike CloudFormation-based self-mutation, PipelineUpdate Target provides:

* **Enhanced security**: Uses proper permission boundaries through Bindles
* **Better customer experience**: More reliable and predictable updates
* **Cleaner separation**: Operates as a regular pipeline target with special capabilities
* **Audit trail**: Clear visibility into pipeline changes through standard deployment mechanisms

When you deploy changes through a PipelineUpdate Target, it automatically:

#. Downloads the build artifacts containing your pipeline definition
#. Parses the pipeline structure file (typically generated by CDK)
#. Compares the desired state with the current pipeline configuration
#. Updates the pipeline to match the desired state

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_configuration:

Configure PipelineUpdate Target with CDK
----------------------------------------

To enable PipelineUpdate Target in your CDK application, set the ``createLegacyPipelineStage``
property to ``false`` in your pipeline configuration:

.. code-block:: typescript

   import { DeploymentPipeline } from '@amzn/pipelines';
   
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target mode
     sourceType: 'CodeCommit',
     defaultCodeCommitBranch: 'mainline',
     defaultCodeCommitRepositoryName: 'MyServiceRepo',
     // ... other configuration
   });

This configuration tells the CDK to use Pipeline Target configuration mode instead of the
Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode, enabling the PipelineUpdate Target functionality.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_permissions:

Set up proper permissions through Bindles
-----------------------------------------

PipelineUpdate Target requires appropriate permissions to modify your pipeline. Configure
these permissions through Bindles to maintain security boundaries:

#. Create a Bindle for your pipeline with the necessary permissions:

   * Pipeline read/write permissions
   * Access to the pipeline's artifact bucket
   * Permissions to assume the pipeline's execution role

#. Associate the Bindle with your pipeline target in the CDK:

   .. code-block:: typescript

      import { PipelineUpdateTarget } from '@amzn/pipelines';
      
      const updateTarget = new PipelineUpdateTarget(this, 'UpdateTarget', {
        pipeline: pipeline,
        bindleId: 'amzn1.bindle.resource.your-bindle-id',
        // Additional configuration as needed
      });

#. Ensure your pipeline's execution role has permissions to deploy the PipelineUpdate Target

Best practices
==============

Use version control for all pipeline changes
--------------------------------------------

Since PipelineUpdate Target treats your pipeline as code, all changes should go through
version control:

* Commit pipeline configuration changes to your repository
* Use code reviews to validate pipeline modifications
* Maintain a clear history of pipeline evolution

Implement gradual rollout strategies
------------------------------------

When making significant pipeline changes:

#. Test changes in a development pipeline first
#. Use feature flags or conditional logic to control rollout
#. Monitor pipeline health metrics during and after updates
#. Have a rollback strategy ready

Validate pipeline changes before deployment
-------------------------------------------

Use the Pipelines CLI to preview changes before they're applied:

.. code-block:: bash

   # View the current pipeline configuration
   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline
   
   # Preview what changes will be made
   pipelines pipeline diff --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
     --template-file pipeline-structure.json
   
   # Deploy the changes
   pipelines pipeline deploy --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
     --template-file pipeline-structure.json

Monitor pipeline update deployments
-----------------------------------

Track the success of your pipeline updates:

* Set up CloudWatch alarms for pipeline update failures
* Monitor deployment duration metrics
* Review CloudWatch Logs for detailed update information
* Use pipeline notifications to alert on update status

Caveats
=======

Limitations of PipelineUpdate Target
------------------------------------

While PipelineUpdate Target can modify most pipeline elements, certain properties cannot
be changed:

* **Pipeline name**: The pipeline identifier must remain constant
* **Pipeline description**: The top-level description is immutable
* **Notification email**: The primary notification email cannot be modified

If you need to change these properties, you must create a new pipeline.

Migration considerations
-----------------------

When migrating from Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode to PipelineUpdate Target:

#. Existing pipeline history and artifacts are preserved
#. The migration is one-way; you cannot revert to Legacy Edit mode
#. Ensure all team members understand the new deployment process
#. Update any automation or scripts that interact with the pipeline

Deployment timing
----------------

PipelineUpdate Target updates occur during the deployment phase:

* Changes are applied when the target is deployed, not immediately on commit
* Pipeline updates may cause temporary disruption to in-flight deployments
* Consider scheduling major updates during maintenance windows

Permission boundaries
--------------------

PipelineUpdate Target operates within strict permission boundaries:

* Cannot modify resources outside the pipeline scope
* Cannot change cross-account permissions without proper authorization
* Must respect organizational policies and compliance requirements

When to use
===========

Recommended scenarios
--------------------

Use PipelineUpdate Target when:

* **Managing complex pipelines**: Multiple stages, environments, and approval workflows
* **Frequent pipeline updates**: Regular additions of new stages or deployment targets
* **Team collaboration**: Multiple developers need to modify pipeline configuration
* **Compliance requirements**: Need audit trail and version control for pipeline changes
* **GitOps workflows**: Desire to manage all infrastructure through code

Alternative approaches
---------------------

Consider alternatives when:

* **Simple, static pipelines**: Pipeline rarely changes after initial setup
* **Emergency fixes**: Need immediate pipeline modifications (use console with caution)
* **Learning phase**: Team is new to IaC concepts (start with console, migrate later)

Migration guide
===============

Step 1: Assess current pipeline configuration
---------------------------------------------

Before migration, document your current pipeline:

.. code-block:: bash

   # Export current pipeline configuration
   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
     --output json > current-pipeline.json
   
   # Review CloudFormation stacks if using Legacy Edit mode
   aws cloudformation describe-stacks \
     --stack-name my-service-pipeline-stack

Step 2: Update CDK configuration
--------------------------------

Modify your CDK application to use PipelineUpdate Target:

.. code-block:: typescript

   // Before (Legacy Edit mode)
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     // createLegacyPipelineStage: true (default)
     // ... other configuration
   });
   
   // After (PipelineUpdate Target mode)
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target
     // ... other configuration
   });

Step 3: Configure Bindles and permissions
-----------------------------------------

#. Create or update Bindles for pipeline permissions:

   * Navigate to the Bindles console
   * Create a new Bindle or update existing one
   * Add necessary pipeline update permissions
   * Associate with your pipeline target

#. Update IAM roles if needed:

   .. code-block:: typescript

      const pipelineRole = new iam.Role(this, 'PipelineRole', {
        assumedBy: new iam.ServicePrincipal('pipelines.amazonaws.com'),
        inlinePolicies: {
          PipelineUpdatePolicy: new iam.PolicyDocument({
            statements: [
              new iam.PolicyStatement({
                actions: ['pipelines:UpdatePipeline'],
                resources: ['*'],
                conditions: {
                  StringEquals: {
                    'pipelines:PipelineName': pipeline.pipelineName,
                  },
                },
              }),
            ],
          }),
        },
      });

Step 4: Test the migration
--------------------------

#. Deploy to a test environment first:

   .. code-block:: bash

      # Synthesize the CDK application
      cdk synth
      
      # Review the generated pipeline structure
      cat cdk.out/pipeline-structure.json
      
      # Deploy to test environment
      cdk deploy --context environment=test

#. Verify pipeline functionality:

   * Trigger a test deployment
   * Verify all stages execute correctly
   * Confirm PipelineUpdate Target is working
   * Check CloudWatch Logs for any issues

Step 5: Production rollout
--------------------------

#. Schedule the migration during a maintenance window
#. Communicate changes to your team
#. Deploy to production:

   .. code-block:: bash

      # Final review of changes
      pipelines pipeline diff --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
        --template-file cdk.out/pipeline-structure.json
      
      # Deploy to production
      cdk deploy --context environment=prod

#. Monitor the migration:

   * Watch CloudWatch metrics
   * Review deployment logs
   * Verify pipeline updates are working
   * Test a sample deployment

Step 6: Post-migration validation
---------------------------------

After migration, ensure everything is working:

#. **Test pipeline updates**: Make a small change and verify it deploys correctly
#. **Validate permissions**: Ensure all team members can still interact with the pipeline
#. **Update documentation**: Document the new process for your team
#. **Train team members**: Ensure everyone understands the new workflow

Troubleshooting
==============

Common issues and solutions
---------------------------

**Pipeline update fails with permission errors**

* Verify Bindle configuration includes all necessary permissions
* Check IAM role trust relationships
* Ensure artifact bucket permissions are correctly configured

**Changes not appearing after deployment**

* Confirm ``createLegacyPipelineStage: false`` is set in CDK
* Verify CDK synthesis is generating the correct pipeline structure
* Check PipelineUpdate Target deployment logs in CloudWatch

**Deployment takes longer than expected**

* Pipeline updates add overhead to deployment time
* Consider batching multiple changes together
* Review CloudWatch metrics for bottlenecks

**Rollback procedures**

If you need to rollback a pipeline change:

.. code-block:: bash

   # Revert the code change
   git revert <commit-hash>
   
   # Synthesize and deploy the reverted version
   cdk synth
   cdk deploy
   
   # Verify the pipeline is restored
   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline

Related documentation
====================

* :doc:`nativedg:create-cdk-pipeline` - Creating CDK-based pipelines
* :doc:`golden-path-iac` - Infrastructure as Code best practices
* :wiki:`Pipelines/PipelineUpdate` - Internal wiki documentation
* :awsdocs:`CDK Pipelines <cdk/v2/guide/cdk_pipeline.html>` - AWS CDK Pipelines guide
* :doc:`changeguardian:index` - Change Guardian for risk analysis

Support
=======

For assistance with PipelineUpdate Target:

* **Slack**: #pipelines-support channel
* **Wiki**: :wiki:`Pipelines/PipelineUpdate/Troubleshooting`
* **Tickets**: Create a ticket with the Pipelines team
* **Office Hours**: Wednesdays 2-3 PM PT

.. include:: includes/reviewers.txt

###########################
 Web service Golden Paths
###########################

.. contents::
   :local:

Available web service Golden Paths
==================================

For web services, we first recommend Lambda, followed by ECS Fargate. The right option for your new
web service can likely be determined by your application's requirements.

.. toctree::
   :titlesonly:
   :maxdepth: 1

    Lambda Golden Path (web service) <https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/web-services/golden-path-lambda/>
    ECS-Fargate Golden Path (web service) <https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/docs/web-services/golden-path-ecs-fargate/>

Which compute type should I choose?
===================================

When choosing a compute target for a new service, we strongly recommend that you select the
platform that allows you to meet customer needs while owning the smallest amount of infrastructure
possible. By using the right level of abstraction, you can spend more time making your customers'
lives better and focus on writing the code of your application instead of spending time maintaining
a vast array of resources that require long-term maintenance.

.. include:: ../shared/request-reply-requirements-table.txt

.. Copyright  2023, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

#####################
Building web services
#####################

.. contents::
   :local:

.. meta::
   :description: Building web services.

.. _golden-path-recommendations-for-web-services:

Web services remain a popular application choice and are a key component of Service Oriented
Architecture (SOA) and microservices. Web services continue to stand the test of time because they
offer a highly distributed, language agnostic, lightweight, and modular API model that can easily
evolve as application requirements change. Moreover, there are a large amount of resources that are
invested at Amazon for building and maintaining highly available services. It is very likely that
web services will continue to be used to build next generation applications and services.

.. list-table::
   :header-rows: 1

   * - If you are building...
     - See...

   * - Web services in Native AWS
     -  :doc:`golden-path-lambda`

        :doc:`golden-path-ecs-fargate`

       :doc:`cdk-howto-ec2`


   * - Web services in PROD/CORP
     - :doc:`develop-prod-corp-web-services`

Which compute target should I use?
==================================

When choosing a compute target for a new service, we strongly recommend that you select the platform
that allows you to meet customer needs while owning the smallest amount of infrastructure possible.
By using the right level of abstraction, you can spend more time making your customers' lives better
and focus on writing the code of your application instead of spending time maintaining a vast array
of resources that require long-term maintenance.

For web services, we first recommend Lambda, followed by ECS Fargate. The right option for your
new web service can likely be determined by your application's requirements:

.. include:: ../shared/request-reply-requirements-table.txt

If your application has requirements that cannot be met by Lambda or ECS Fargate, including special
hardware requirements, new region availability requirements, or the need to avoid circular
dependencies, we recommend EC2. For more information, see :doc:`webservices:cdk-howto-ec2`.

Golden Path recommendations for web services
============================================

There are many factors to consider when building and deploying web services for production. The
Golden Path program publishes many recommendations that generally provide the best opportunity for
creating successful services and applications given the vast options and tooling available from AWS
and BuilderTools. The recommendations are reviewed and updated on a regular basis to ensure they
remain technically accurate and current.

* :doc:`goldenpath:index`

*  :doc:`golden-path-lambda`: A set of recommendations and best practices to consider when
  deploying web services on Lambda.

*  :doc:`golden-path-ecs-fargate`: A set of recommendations and best practices to consider
  when deploying web services on ECS and Fargate.

Web service frameworks
======================

Coral and Smithy are the web service frameworks that are being used at scale across many teams
at Amazon and AWS. These frameworks allow teams to focus on creating business logic rather
than managing low-level web service technologies or extending existing frameworks to work with
AWS tools.

* :wiki:`Coral`: Coral is a proprietary web service framework for creating and hosting RPC and REST
  services. Coral includes both server-side frameworks and automatic client code generation in a
  number of popular languages. Coral includes a rich set of features, which include tools for
  developing and deploying services, serialization, throttling, metrics, management, security, and
  more.

* :wiki:`Smithy`: Smithy is an Interface Definition Language (IDL) and set of tools that allows
  developers to build clients and servers in multiple languages. Smithy models define a service as a
  collection of resources, operations, and shapes. A Smithy model enables API providers to generate
  clients and servers in various programming languages, API documentation, test automation, and
  example code. Although Coral includes its own IDL, Smithy is an evolution of that model and Smithy
  is now the preferred way to model web services.


Web service tutorials
=====================

The quickest way to get started standing up web services is to use |bhcreate|_. In particular,
|bhcreate| includes |bhcreate-srcapps|_ that provide the necessary setup and integration code
required to develop, build, and deploy web services. The following tutorials make use of the
|bhcreate-srcapps| and are recommended if you are new to development at AWS.

* :doc:`nativedg:create-cle-java-lambda`: This tutorial steps through creating a
  :bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral Service on Lambda <cle-java-lambda>` application using |bhcreate|. This
  application can be used as a starting point for the  :doc:`golden-path-lambda`.

* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-ecs`: This tutorial steps through creating a :bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral
  Service on Fargate <coral-fargate>` application using |bhcreate| and also includes additional
  steps that demonstrate common development and deployment tasks. This application can be used as a
  starting point for the  :doc:`golden-path-ecs-fargate`.

.. toctree::
   :hidden:
   :titlesonly:

    Lambda Golden Path (web service) <golden-path-lambda>
    ECS-Fargate Golden Path (web service) <golden-path-ecs-fargate>
   cdk-howto-ec2
   develop-prod-corp-web-services

    13################################
    14
    15.. meta::
    16   :description: Lambda Golden Path (Web Service)
    17
    18.. contents::
    19   :depth: 2
    20   :local:
    21
    22.. toctree::
    23   :hidden:
    24
    25   Infrastructure management <golden-path-iac>
    26   Scaffolding resources <golden-path-scaffolding>
    27   Dependency management <golden-path-dependency-management>
    28   CloudFormation stack management <golden-path-cloudformation-stack-management>

    31   DNS <golden-path-dns>
