    33   PROD/CORP connectivity <golden-path-corp-prod-connectivity>
    34   Service framework <golden-path-lambda-service-framework>
    35   Function configuration <golden-path-lambda-function-configuration>
    36   Configuration management <golden-path-configuration-management>
    37   Authentication and authorization <golden-path-lambda-auth>
    38   Production deployment <golden-path-lambda-production-deployment>
    39   Local development <golden-path-lambda-local-development>
    40   Integration testing <golden-path-integration-testing>
    41   Load, fuzz, and canary testing <golden-path-other-testing>
    42   Logging <golden-path-lambda-logging>
    43   Monitoring and alarms <golden-path-lambda-monitoring-alarms>
    44   Dashboards <golden-path-dashboards>
    45   Troubleshooting <golden-path-lambda-troubleshooting>
    46
    47Overview
    48========
    49
    50:aws:`AWS Lambda <lambda>` is the most abstract compute platform to date. It
    51allows developers to build and scale easily without having to worry about the
    52burden of maintaining the underlying platforms. The uniqueness of Lambda's
    53Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) model and gaps of existing services make it
    54challenging for developers who develop new applications or migrate existing ones
    55from other platforms. Lambda golden path guide provides recommendations for
    56aspects that you should consider when designing and building your serverless
    57applications.
    58
    59With Lambda, you can run code for virtually any type of application or back-end
    60service. For the purpose of this article, we target a Lambda application with the
    61following profile:
    62
    63* A request/response service operating at 1,000 TPS or less. By default, Lambda
    64  supports up to 1,000 concurrent executions. Concurrent executions are related to
    65  TPS, `but they are not the same`__. AWS Premium Support can increase this
    66  :awsdocs:`limit <lambda/latest/dg/gettingstarted-limits.html>`
    67  to an extent and with turnaround time. The recommendations in this guide have not
    68  been vetted for workloads exceeding 1,000 TPS.
    69
    70  .. __: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/compute/understanding-aws-lambdas-invoke-throttle-limits/
    71* The service supports service-to-service authentication and commits to an
    72  availability level of 99.95% uptime.
    73
    74Many recommendations still apply to other Lambda application types although
    75they are not the focus of this topic.
    76
    77Getting started
    78===============
    79
    80If you are creating a new application, or if you just want to experiment with running a web service

################################
Lambda Golden Path (web service)
################################

.. meta::
   :description: Lambda Golden Path (Web Service)

.. contents::
   :depth: 2
   :local:

.. toctree::
   :hidden:

   Infrastructure management <golden-path-iac>
   Scaffolding resources <golden-path-scaffolding>
   Dependency management <golden-path-dependency-management>
   CloudFormation stack management <golden-path-cloudformation-stack-management>
   VPC <golden-path-vpc>
   Load balancer <golden-path-lambda-load-balancer>
   DNS <golden-path-dns>
   Certificate management <golden-path-certificate-management>
   PROD/CORP connectivity <golden-path-corp-prod-connectivity>
   Service framework <golden-path-lambda-service-framework>
   Function configuration <golden-path-lambda-function-configuration>
   Configuration management <golden-path-configuration-management>
   Authentication and authorization <golden-path-lambda-auth>
   Production deployment <golden-path-lambda-production-deployment>
   Local development <golden-path-lambda-local-development>
   Integration testing <golden-path-integration-testing>
   Load, fuzz, and canary testing <golden-path-other-testing>
   Logging <golden-path-lambda-logging>
   Monitoring and alarms <golden-path-lambda-monitoring-alarms>
   Dashboards <golden-path-dashboards>
   Troubleshooting <golden-path-lambda-troubleshooting>

Overview
========

:aws:`AWS Lambda <lambda>` is the most abstract compute platform to date. It
allows developers to build and scale easily without having to worry about the
burden of maintaining the underlying platforms. The uniqueness of Lambda's
Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) model and gaps of existing services make it
challenging for developers who develop new applications or migrate existing ones
from other platforms. Lambda golden path guide provides recommendations for
aspects that you should consider when designing and building your serverless
applications.

With Lambda, you can run code for virtually any type of application or back-end
service. For the purpose of this article, we target a Lambda application with the
following profile:

* A request/response service operating at 1,000 TPS or less. By default, Lambda
  supports up to 1,000 concurrent executions. Concurrent executions are related to
  TPS, `but they are not the same`__. AWS Premium Support can increase this
  :awsdocs:`limit <lambda/latest/dg/gettingstarted-limits.html>`
  to an extent and with turnaround time. The recommendations in this guide have not
  been vetted for workloads exceeding 1,000 TPS.

  .. __: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/compute/understanding-aws-lambdas-invoke-throttle-limits/
* The service supports service-to-service authentication and commits to an
  availability level of 99.95% uptime.

Many recommendations still apply to other Lambda application types although
they are not the focus of this topic.

Getting started
===============

If you are creating a new application, or if you just want to experiment with running a web service
on Lambda in a low-risk environment, we recommend that you start with the
:bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral Service on Lambda <cle-java-lambda>` sample application on |bhcreate|,
which provides as many of the Golden Path recommendations as possible (those that are supported by
automation) out of the box.

For detailed instructions on creating and deploying the sample application, see the
:doc:`nativedg:create-cle-java-lambda` tutorial.

Feedback
========

If you have any feedback on the recommendations made in this document, please
use the :guilabel:`Provide feedback` link at the bottom of the page to create
an issue.

We intend for this to be a living document that is updated as we, as a company,
learn about sharp edges and evolving best practices. Your feedback is invaluable
in helping us understand where our recommendations need further attention.

General advice
==============

Prefer Native AWS solutions, avoid taking PROD/CORP dependencies
----------------------------------------------------------------

When choosing the infrastructure for your application, try to use as many Native AWS solutions as
possible, and avoid taking dependencies on PROD/CORP if possible. For example, you should prefer
:aws:`AWS Secrets Manager <secrets-manager/>` over :doc:`btools:products-odin` for distributing
secrets, :aws:`AWS AppConfig <systems-manager/features/appconfig>` over :wiki:`Safe Dynamic Config
<AWSRegionBuildEngineering/Safe%20Dynamic%20Config>` for managing application configurations, or
:aws:`AWS ACM <certificate-manager/>` over :doc:`btools:products-redfort` for TLS certificate
management.


Avoid using AWS services that depend on your service
----------------------------------------------------

Circular dependency between AWS services happens when two services, either directly or indirectly,
depend on each other. This relationship introduces a high risk of blocking new region builds. Before
taking up our recommendations on a specific AWS service, make sure you are not a dependency of that
service.  This advice applies to AWS Lambda, too. If you are one of the services that Lambda depends
on (such as DynamoDB, EC2, or S3), you should not use Lambda.

TypeScript. You must use TypeScript for your CDK application if you need to
use Mote.


Non-recommended options
=======================

Raw CloudFormation templates
----------------------------

Raw CloudFormation templates are based on markup languages (YAML or JSON), not real programming
languages. Thus writing CloudFormation template directly is repetitive and error-prone. AWS
CDK still generates CloudFormation templates and leverages all great features of CloudFormation
such as safe deployment, automatic rollback, and drift detection. At the same time, AWS CDK
makes it easier to write code (thanks to IDE's code completion feature) and stand up
complex infrastructure with less and reusable code (the :awsdocs:`developer guide <cdk/v2/guide/home.html>`
showcases a 20-line CDK application that can do the job of a 500-line CloudFormation template).

Terraform
---------

One of the selling points of Terraform is being cloud-provider-agnostic which is not applicable for
Amazon's internal teams. It introduces its own syntax which is more friendly than YAML and
JSON but it's still not a real programming language.

Terraform is an open-source software and Amazon does not have influence on its prioritization. The
software may run behind CDK and CloudFormation when it comes to supporting new features of AWS services.

Relevant tooling
================

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_mote_cdk:

(SDO only) Mote
---------------

:wiki:`Mote <Infosec/CloudSecurity/SecureDefaults/MoteCDK/>` (or MoteCDK) is a set of CDK constructs
that extend the vanilla AWS CDK constructs with some secure-by-default configurations. They can
be used inline and interchangeably with the external CDK constructs. See the `API reference
<https://highcastle.a2z.com/docs/mote-home/index.html>`__ for more details. Mote is only available
for SDO teams. Although MoteCDK is actively supported and it provides high compatibilty level with the
vanilla CDK constructs, it is planned to be replaced by SecureCDK in the future.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_secure_cdk:

Secure CDK
----------

:wiki:`Secure CDK <Security/SecureCDK>`, a replacement of CDK and a successor of MoteCDK, is a

#######################################
Golden Path - infrastructure management
#######################################

.. meta::
   :description: Golden Path - Infrastructure management

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendations
===============

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_cdk:

Use AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK)
-----------------------------------

AWS CDK is a framework to model and provision AWS resources and internal resources
using familiar programming languages. Unlike legacy CfnBuild-based applications, which build a
single CloudFormation template per stack for deployment through a pipeline, CDK produces one
CloudFormation template per deployment target in a pipeline.

When using the CDK, avoid using **AWS CloudFormation-only** (L1) constructs where possible. Use
**Curated** (L2) constructs instead. Use **Pattern** (L3) constructs only when you are certain you
do not need to customize the underlying resources. Pattern constructs couple the fate of the
resources they create. The ``NetworkLoadBalancedFargateService`` construct, for example, implies
an abstraction when none actually exists; the construct automates the configuration of both an NLB
and Fargate service, but you still own the fundamental resources. The pattern construct may also
be opinionated in its configuration in a way that does not apply to your service. Alternatively,
the ``DeploymentPipeline`` pattern construct configures an internal Pipeline and may be an
acceptable tradeoff between automation and resource coupling. See
:awsdocs:`CDK key concepts <cdk/latest/guide/getting_started.html#getting_started_concepts>`
for more information about the three fundamental flavors of CDK constructs.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_pipelines:

Automate your infrastructure deployment with Pipelines
------------------------------------------------------

Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps
required to release your software. It picks up the CloudFormation templates generated from your CDK
application, and deploys them to the destinations configured in your pipeline definition.

Your pipeline definition is also managed by CDK using the `@amzn/pipelines`_ package.
Behind the scene, the pipeline definition is presented as a :wiki:`self-service CloudFormation resource <AWS21/Self_Service/>`.
|bhub-create|_ provides a number of options to create applications with pipelines managed by the CDK.

.. _`@amzn/pipelines`: https://devcentral.amazon.com/ac/brazil/package-master/package/go/?flavor=private&path=typedoc/index.html&name=PipelinesConstructs&interface=4.0.0&versionSet=AmznPipelinesConstructs/development&platform=AL2_x86_64


How-tos
=======

* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-lambda-cdk`.
* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-ecs`.

Caveats
=======


Feature parity with LPT
-----------------------

Although the CDK can be seen as the replacement of :doc:`Live Pipeline Templates (LPT) <lptug:index>`
as a tool to manage your infrastructure, some resources are still not available via officially supported
CDK constructs. Teams that vend internal resources must onboard with
:wiki:`Uluru <AWS21/Design/Uluru>` for CloudFormation in order to make the resources available in
the CDK.

The workaround is to use LPT to manage resources that are yet to be supported by CDK. Migrate to the
CDK as soon as the resources are supported. Refer to the :doc:`LPT user guide <lptug:getting-started>`
to get started with LPT.


MoteCDK language support
------------------------

:wiki:`Mote <Infosec/CloudSecurity/SecureDefaults/MoteCDK/>` only supports
TypeScript. You must use TypeScript for your CDK application if you need to
use Mote.


Non-recommended options
=======================

Raw CloudFormation templates
----------------------------

Raw CloudFormation templates are based on markup languages (YAML or JSON), not real programming
languages. Thus writing CloudFormation template directly is repetitive and error-prone. AWS
CDK still generates CloudFormation templates and leverages all great features of CloudFormation
such as safe deployment, automatic rollback, and drift detection. At the same time, AWS CDK
makes it easier to write code (thanks to IDE's code completion feature) and stand up
complex infrastructure with less and reusable code (the :awsdocs:`developer guide <cdk/v2/guide/home.html>`
showcases a 20-line CDK application that can do the job of a 500-line CloudFormation template).

Terraform
---------

One of the selling points of Terraform is being cloud-provider-agnostic which is not applicable for
Amazon's internal teams. It introduces its own syntax which is more friendly than YAML and
JSON but it's still not a real programming language.

Terraform is an open-source software and Amazon does not have influence on its prioritization. The
software may run behind CDK and CloudFormation when it comes to supporting new features of AWS services.

Relevant tooling
================

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_mote_cdk:

(SDO only) Mote
---------------

:wiki:`Mote <Infosec/CloudSecurity/SecureDefaults/MoteCDK/>` (or MoteCDK) is a set of CDK constructs
that extend the vanilla AWS CDK constructs with some secure-by-default configurations. They can
be used inline and interchangeably with the external CDK constructs. See the `API reference
<https://highcastle.a2z.com/docs/mote-home/index.html>`__ for more details. Mote is only available
for SDO teams. Although MoteCDK is actively supported and it provides high compatibilty level with the
vanilla CDK constructs, it is planned to be replaced by SecureCDK in the future.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_secure_cdk:

Secure CDK
----------

:wiki:`Secure CDK <Security/SecureCDK>`, a replacement of CDK and a successor of MoteCDK, is a
solution created by a collaboration between security teams from AWS and SDO. SecureCDK addresses
misconfigurations in the vanilla CDK library, avoiding service from being flagged by security scanners
or pentesters out of the box. The current implementation of Secure CDK is effectively a fork of the
public CDK library. New services can use Secure CDK today, but should take into account the implication
of using a forked library, considering the common issues of compatibility and availability, as well
as the :wiki:`known issues <SecureCDK/Considerations>`.

A re-implementation of Secure CDK, which will be type-compatible with CDK, is being
planned by Security Foundations and AWS CDK teams (:github:`GitHub <aws/aws-cdk-rfcs/issues/693>`).
See :wiki:`Secure CDK Blueprint <SecureCDK/Blueprint>`.

Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_pipelineupdate:

Use PipelineUpdate Target for self-mutating pipelines
-----------------------------------------------------

When your pipeline needs to update itself based on code changes (Infrastructure as Code), use 
PipelineUpdate Target instead of CloudFormation-based self-mutation. PipelineUpdate Target provides
better security through Bindles, improved reliability, and cleaner separation of concerns. See
:doc:`golden-path-pipelineupdate-target` for detailed guidance on implementation and migration.

toolUseResult.oldString:
Automate your infrastructure deployment with Pipelines
------------------------------------------------------

Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps
required to release your software. It picks up the CloudFormation templates generated from your CDK
application, and deploys them to the destinations configured in your pipeline definition.

Your pipeline definition is also managed by CDK using the `@amzn/pipelines`_ package.
Behind the scene, the pipeline definition is presented as a :wiki:`self-service CloudFormation resource <AWS21/Self_Service/>`.
|bhub-create|_ provides a number of options to create applications with pipelines managed by the CDK.

.. _`@amzn/pipelines`: https://devcentral.amazon.com/ac/brazil/package-master/package/go/?flavor=private&path=typedoc/index.html&name=PipelinesConstructs&interface=4.0.0&versionSet=AmznPipelinesConstructs/development&platform=AL2_x86_64
toolUseResult.newString:
Automate your infrastructure deployment with Pipelines
------------------------------------------------------

Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps
required to release your software. It picks up the CloudFormation templates generated from your CDK
application, and deploys them to the destinations configured in your pipeline definition.

Your pipeline definition is also managed by CDK using the `@amzn/pipelines`_ package.
Behind the scene, the pipeline definition is presented as a :wiki:`self-service CloudFormation resource <AWS21/Self_Service/>`.
|bhub-create|_ provides a number of options to create applications with pipelines managed by the CDK.

.. _`@amzn/pipelines`: https://devcentral.amazon.com/ac/brazil/package-master/package/go/?flavor=private&path=typedoc/index.html&name=PipelinesConstructs&interface=4.0.0&versionSet=AmznPipelinesConstructs/development&platform=AL2_x86_64

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_pipelineupdate:

Use PipelineUpdate Target for self-mutating pipelines
-----------------------------------------------------

When your pipeline needs to update itself based on code changes (Infrastructure as Code), use 
PipelineUpdate Target instead of CloudFormation-based self-mutation. PipelineUpdate Target provides
better security through Bindles, improved reliability, and cleaner separation of concerns. See
:doc:`golden-path-pipelineupdate-target` for detailed guidance on implementation and migration.
toolUseResult.originalFile:
.. Copyright  2023, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

#######################################
Golden Path - infrastructure management
#######################################

.. meta::
   :description: Golden Path - Infrastructure management

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendations
===============

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_cdk:

Use AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK)
-----------------------------------

AWS CDK is a framework to model and provision AWS resources and internal resources
using familiar programming languages. Unlike legacy CfnBuild-based applications, which build a
single CloudFormation template per stack for deployment through a pipeline, CDK produces one
CloudFormation template per deployment target in a pipeline.

When using the CDK, avoid using **AWS CloudFormation-only** (L1) constructs where possible. Use
**Curated** (L2) constructs instead. Use **Pattern** (L3) constructs only when you are certain you
do not need to customize the underlying resources. Pattern constructs couple the fate of the
resources they create. The ``NetworkLoadBalancedFargateService`` construct, for example, implies
an abstraction when none actually exists; the construct automates the configuration of both an NLB
and Fargate service, but you still own the fundamental resources. The pattern construct may also
be opinionated in its configuration in a way that does not apply to your service. Alternatively,
the ``DeploymentPipeline`` pattern construct configures an internal Pipeline and may be an
acceptable tradeoff between automation and resource coupling. See
:awsdocs:`CDK key concepts <cdk/latest/guide/getting_started.html#getting_started_concepts>`
for more information about the three fundamental flavors of CDK constructs.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_pipelines:

Automate your infrastructure deployment with Pipelines
------------------------------------------------------

Pipelines is an internal continuous deployment tool to model, visualize, and automate the steps
required to release your software. It picks up the CloudFormation templates generated from your CDK
application, and deploys them to the destinations configured in your pipeline definition.

Your pipeline definition is also managed by CDK using the `@amzn/pipelines`_ package.
Behind the scene, the pipeline definition is presented as a :wiki:`self-service CloudFormation resource <AWS21/Self_Service/>`.
|bhub-create|_ provides a number of options to create applications with pipelines managed by the CDK.

.. _`@amzn/pipelines`: https://devcentral.amazon.com/ac/brazil/package-master/package/go/?flavor=private&path=typedoc/index.html&name=PipelinesConstructs&interface=4.0.0&versionSet=AmznPipelinesConstructs/development&platform=AL2_x86_64


How-tos
=======

* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-lambda-cdk`.
* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-ecs`.
* :doc:`golden-path-pipelineupdate-target` - Managing pipeline self-mutation with PipelineUpdate Target.

Caveats
=======


Feature parity with LPT
-----------------------

Although the CDK can be seen as the replacement of :doc:`Live Pipeline Templates (LPT) <lptug:index>`
as a tool to manage your infrastructure, some resources are still not available via officially supported
CDK constructs. Teams that vend internal resources must onboard with
:wiki:`Uluru <AWS21/Design/Uluru>` for CloudFormation in order to make the resources available in
the CDK.

The workaround is to use LPT to manage resources that are yet to be supported by CDK. Migrate to the
CDK as soon as the resources are supported. Refer to the :doc:`LPT user guide <lptug:getting-started>`
to get started with LPT.


MoteCDK language support
------------------------

:wiki:`Mote <Infosec/CloudSecurity/SecureDefaults/MoteCDK/>` only supports
TypeScript. You must use TypeScript for your CDK application if you need to
use Mote.


Non-recommended options
=======================

Raw CloudFormation templates
----------------------------

Raw CloudFormation templates are based on markup languages (YAML or JSON), not real programming
languages. Thus writing CloudFormation template directly is repetitive and error-prone. AWS
CDK still generates CloudFormation templates and leverages all great features of CloudFormation
such as safe deployment, automatic rollback, and drift detection. At the same time, AWS CDK
makes it easier to write code (thanks to IDE's code completion feature) and stand up
complex infrastructure with less and reusable code (the :awsdocs:`developer guide <cdk/v2/guide/home.html>`
showcases a 20-line CDK application that can do the job of a 500-line CloudFormation template).

Terraform
---------

One of the selling points of Terraform is being cloud-provider-agnostic which is not applicable for
Amazon's internal teams. It introduces its own syntax which is more friendly than YAML and
JSON but it's still not a real programming language.

Terraform is an open-source software and Amazon does not have influence on its prioritization. The
software may run behind CDK and CloudFormation when it comes to supporting new features of AWS services.

Relevant tooling
================

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_mote_cdk:

(SDO only) Mote
---------------

:wiki:`Mote <Infosec/CloudSecurity/SecureDefaults/MoteCDK/>` (or MoteCDK) is a set of CDK constructs
that extend the vanilla AWS CDK constructs with some secure-by-default configurations. They can
be used inline and interchangeably with the external CDK constructs. See the `API reference
<https://highcastle.a2z.com/docs/mote-home/index.html>`__ for more details. Mote is only available
for SDO teams. Although MoteCDK is actively supported and it provides high compatibilty level with the
vanilla CDK constructs, it is planned to be replaced by SecureCDK in the future.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_iac_secure_cdk:

Secure CDK
----------

:wiki:`Secure CDK <Security/SecureCDK>`, a replacement of CDK and a successor of MoteCDK, is a
solution created by a collaboration between security teams from AWS and SDO. SecureCDK addresses
misconfigurations in the vanilla CDK library, avoiding service from being flagged by security scanners
or pentesters out of the box. The current implementation of Secure CDK is effectively a fork of the
public CDK library. New services can use Secure CDK today, but should take into account the implication
of using a forked library, considering the common issues of compatibility and availability, as well
as the :wiki:`known issues <SecureCDK/Considerations>`.

A re-implementation of Secure CDK, which will be type-compatible with CDK, is being
planned by Security Foundations and AWS CDK teams (:github:`GitHub <aws/aws-cdk-rfcs/issues/693>`).
See :wiki:`Secure CDK Blueprint <SecureCDK/Blueprint>`.

+better security through Bindles, improved reliability, and cleaner separation of concerns. See
+:doc:`golden-path-pipelineupdate-target` for detailed guidance on implementation and migration.

## Created Documentation

### 1. Main Golden Path Document
**File**: `web_services/golden-path-pipelineupdate-target.rst`

This comprehensive document includes:
- **Recommendations** for adopting PipelineUpdate Target for pipeline self-mutation
- **Best practices** including version control, gradual rollout, and monitoring
- **Detailed migration guide** from Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode
- **Troubleshooting section** for common issues
- **Code examples** in TypeScript and bash
- **Proper cross-references** to related documentation

### 2. Updated Infrastructure as Code Document
**File**: `web_services/golden-path-iac.rst`
- Added PipelineUpdate Target as a recommended approach
- Included new section on self-mutating pipelines
- Added reference to the new golden path document

## Key Features

The documentation follows all BuilderHub style guidelines:
-  Copyright header and contribution links
-  Second person voice throughout
-  Active voice and sentence case headings
-  Proper RST formatting with reference labels
-  Cross-references to AWS services

content.content:
1.. Copyright  2025, Amazon, LLC.
     2
     3   ** Contributions are always welcome! **
     4
     5   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
     6   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html
     7
     8   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
     9   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/
    10
    11##################################################
    12Golden Path - PipelineUpdate Target for Pipelines
    13##################################################
    14
    15.. meta::
    16   :description: Golden Path - PipelineUpdate Target for managing pipelines as code
    17
    18.. contents::
    19   :local:
    20
    21Recommendations
    22===============
    23
    24.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_target:
    25
    26Use PipelineUpdate Target for pipeline self-mutation
    27----------------------------------------------------
    28
    29PipelineUpdate Target is a specialized pipeline target that enables automatic pipeline updates using
    30Infrastructure as Code (IaC) principles. It allows your pipeline to update itself by downloading
    31build artifacts, parsing the pipeline structure file, and applying changes during deployments.
    32
    33Unlike CloudFormation-based self-mutation, PipelineUpdate Target provides:
    34
    35* **Enhanced security**: Uses proper permission boundaries through Bindles
    36* **Better customer experience**: More reliable and predictable updates
    37* **Cleaner separation**: Operates as a regular pipeline target with special capabilities
    38* **Audit trail**: Clear visibility into pipeline changes through standard deployment mechanisms
    39
    40When you deploy changes through a PipelineUpdate Target, it automatically:
    41
    42#. Downloads the build artifacts containing your pipeline definition
    43#. Parses the pipeline structure file (typically generated by CDK)
    44#. Compares the desired state with the current pipeline configuration
    45#. Updates the pipeline to match the desired state
    46
    47.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_configuration:
    48
    49Configure PipelineUpdate Target with CDK
    50----------------------------------------
    51
    52To enable PipelineUpdate Target in your CDK application, set the ``createLegacyPipelineStage``
    53property to ``false`` in your pipeline configuration:
    54
    55.. code-block:: typescript
    56
    57   import { DeploymentPipeline } from '@amzn/pipelines';
    58   
    59   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
    60     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
    61     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target mode
    62     sourceType: 'CodeCommit',
    63     defaultCodeCommitBranch: 'mainline',
    64     defaultCodeCommitRepositoryName: 'MyServiceRepo',
    65     // ... other configuration
    66   });
    67
    68This configuration tells the CDK to use Pipeline Target configuration mode instead of the
    69Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode, enabling the PipelineUpdate Target functionality.
    70
    71.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_permissions:
    72
    73Set up proper permissions through Bindles
    74-----------------------------------------
    75
    76PipelineUpdate Target requires appropriate permissions to modify your pipeline. Configure
    77these permissions through Bindles to maintain security boundaries:
    78
    79#. Create a Bindle for your pipeline with the necessary permissions:
    80
    81   * Pipeline read/write permissions
    82   * Access to the pipeline's artifact bucket
    83   * Permissions to assume the pipeline's execution role
    84
    85#. Associate the Bindle with your pipeline target in the CDK:
    86
    87   .. code-block:: typescript
    88
    89      import { PipelineUpdateTarget } from '@amzn/pipelines';
    90      
    91      const updateTarget = new PipelineUpdateTarget(this, 'UpdateTarget', {
    92        pipeline: pipeline,
    93        bindleId: 'amzn1.bindle.resource.your-bindle-id',
    94        // Additional configuration as needed
    95      });
    96
    97#. Ensure your pipeline's execution role has permissions to deploy the PipelineUpdate Target
    98
    99Best practices
   100==============
   101
   102Use version control for all pipeline changes
   103--------------------------------------------
   104
   105Since PipelineUpdate Target treats your pipeline as code, all changes should go through
   106version control:
   107
   108* Commit pipeline configuration changes to your repository
   109* Use code reviews to validate pipeline modifications
   110* Maintain a clear history of pipeline evolution
   111
   112Implement gradual rollout strategies
   113------------------------------------
   114
   115When making significant pipeline changes:
   116
   117#. Test changes in a development pipeline first
   118#. Use feature flags or conditional logic to control rollout
   119#. Monitor pipeline health metrics during and after updates
   120#. Have a rollback strategy ready
   121
   122Validate pipeline changes before deployment
   123-------------------------------------------
   124
   125Use the Pipelines CLI to preview changes before they're applied:
   126
   127.. code-block:: bash
   128
   129   # View the current pipeline configuration
   130   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline
   131   
   132   # Preview what changes will be made
   133   pipelines pipeline diff --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
   134     --template-file pipeline-structure.json
   135   
   136   # Deploy the changes
   137   pipelines pipeline deploy --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
   138     --template-file pipeline-structure.json
   139
   140Monitor pipeline update deployments
   141-----------------------------------
   142
   143Track the success of your pipeline updates:
   144
   145* Set up CloudWatch alarms for pipeline update failures
   146* Monitor deployment duration metrics
   147* Review CloudWatch Logs for detailed update information
   148* Use pipeline notifications to alert on update status
   149
   150Caveats
   151=======
   152
   153Limitations of PipelineUpdate Target
   154------------------------------------
   155
   156While PipelineUpdate Target can modify most pipeline elements, certain properties cannot
   157be changed:
   158
   159* **Pipeline name**: The pipeline identifier must remain constant
   160* **Pipeline description**: The top-level description is immutable
   161* **Notification email**: The primary notification email cannot be modified
   162
   163If you need to change these properties, you must create a new pipeline.
   164
   165Migration considerations
   166-----------------------
   167
   168When migrating from Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode to PipelineUpdate Target:
   169
   170#. Existing pipeline history and artifacts are preserved
   171#. The migration is one-way; you cannot revert to Legacy Edit mode
   172#. Ensure all team members understand the new deployment process
   173#. Update any automation or scripts that interact with the pipeline
   174
   175Deployment timing
   176----------------
   177
   178PipelineUpdate Target updates occur during the deployment phase:
   179
   180* Changes are applied when the target is deployed, not immediately on commit
   181* Pipeline updates may cause temporary disruption to in-flight deployments
   182* Consider scheduling major updates during maintenance windows
   183
   184Permission boundaries
   185--------------------
   186
   187PipelineUpdate Target operates within strict permission boundaries:
   188
   189* Cannot modify resources outside the pipeline scope
   190* Cannot change cross-account permissions without proper authorization
   191* Must respect organizational policies and compliance requirements
   192
   193When to use
   194===========
   195
   196Recommended scenarios
   197--------------------
   198
   199Use PipelineUpdate Target when:
   200
   201* **Managing complex pipelines**: Multiple stages, environments, and approval workflows
   202* **Frequent pipeline updates**: Regular additions of new stages or deployment targets
   203* **Team collaboration**: Multiple developers need to modify pipeline configuration
   204* **Compliance requirements**: Need audit trail and version control for pipeline changes
   205* **GitOps workflows**: Desire to manage all infrastructure through code
   206
   207Alternative approaches
   208---------------------
   209
   210Consider alternatives when:
   211
   212* **Simple, static pipelines**: Pipeline rarely changes after initial setup
   213* **Emergency fixes**: Need immediate pipeline modifications (use console with caution)
   214* **Learning phase**: Team is new to IaC concepts (start with console, migrate later)
   215
   216Migration guide
   217===============
   218
   219Step 1: Assess current pipeline configuration
   220---------------------------------------------
   221
   222Before migration, document your current pipeline:
   223
   224.. code-block:: bash
   225
   226   # Export current pipeline configuration
   227   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
   228     --output json > current-pipeline.json
   229   
   230   # Review CloudFormation stacks if using Legacy Edit mode
   231   aws cloudformation describe-stacks \
   232     --stack-name my-service-pipeline-stack
   233
   234Step 2: Update CDK configuration
   235--------------------------------
   236
   237Modify your CDK application to use PipelineUpdate Target:
   238
   239.. code-block:: typescript
   240
   241   // Before (Legacy Edit mode)
   242   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
   243     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
   244     // createLegacyPipelineStage: true (default)
   245     // ... other configuration
   246   });
   247   
   248   // After (PipelineUpdate Target mode)
   249   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
   250     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
   251     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target
   252     // ... other configuration
   253   });
   254
   255Step 3: Configure Bindles and permissions
   256-----------------------------------------
   257
   258#. Create or update Bindles for pipeline permissions:
   259
   260   * Navigate to the Bindles console
   261   * Create a new Bindle or update existing one
   262   * Add necessary pipeline update permissions
   263   * Associate with your pipeline target
   264
   265#. Update IAM roles if needed:
   266
   267   .. code-block:: typescript
   268
   269      const pipelineRole = new iam.Role(this, 'PipelineRole', {
   270        assumedBy: new iam.ServicePrincipal('pipelines.amazonaws.com'),
   271        inlinePolicies: {
   272          PipelineUpdatePolicy: new iam.PolicyDocument({
   273            statements: [
   274              new iam.PolicyStatement({
   275                actions: ['pipelines:UpdatePipeline'],
   276                resources: ['*'],
   277                conditions: {
   278                  StringEquals: {
   279                    'pipelines:PipelineName': pipeline.pipelineName,
   280                  },
   281                },
   282              }),
   283            ],
   284          }),
   285        },
   286      });
   287
   288Step 4: Test the migration
   289--------------------------
   290
   291#. Deploy to a test environment first:
   292
   293   .. code-block:: bash
   294
   295      # Synthesize the CDK application
   296      cdk synth
   297      
   298      # Review the generated pipeline structure
   299      cat cdk.out/pipeline-structure.json
   300      
   301      # Deploy to test environment
   302      cdk deploy --context environment=test
   303
   304#. Verify pipeline functionality:
   305
   306   * Trigger a test deployment
   307   * Verify all stages execute correctly
   308   * Confirm PipelineUpdate Target is working
   309   * Check CloudWatch Logs for any issues
   310
   311Step 5: Production rollout
   312--------------------------
   313
   314#. Schedule the migration during a maintenance window
   315#. Communicate changes to your team
   316#. Deploy to production:
   317
   318   .. code-block:: bash
   319
   320      # Final review of changes
   321      pipelines pipeline diff --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
   322        --template-file cdk.out/pipeline-structure.json
   323      
   324      # Deploy to production
   325      cdk deploy --context environment=prod
   326
   327#. Monitor the migration:
   328
   329   * Watch CloudWatch metrics
   330   * Review deployment logs
   331   * Verify pipeline updates are working
   332   * Test a sample deployment
   333
   334Step 6: Post-migration validation
   335---------------------------------
   336
   337After migration, ensure everything is working:
   338
   339#. **Test pipeline updates**: Make a small change and verify it deploys correctly
   340#. **Validate permissions**: Ensure all team members can still interact with the pipeline
   341#. **Update documentation**: Document the new process for your team
   342#. **Train team members**: Ensure everyone understands the new workflow
   343
   344Troubleshooting
   345==============
   346
   347Common issues and solutions
   348---------------------------
   349
   350**Pipeline update fails with permission errors**
   351
   352* Verify Bindle configuration includes all necessary permissions
   353* Check IAM role trust relationships
   354* Ensure artifact bucket permissions are correctly configured
   355
   356**Changes not appearing after deployment**
   357
   358* Confirm ``createLegacyPipelineStage: false`` is set in CDK
   359* Verify CDK synthesis is generating the correct pipeline structure
   360* Check PipelineUpdate Target deployment logs in CloudWatch
   361
   362**Deployment takes longer than expected**
   363
   364* Pipeline updates add overhead to deployment time
   365* Consider batching multiple changes together
   366* Review CloudWatch metrics for bottlenecks
   367
   368**Rollback procedures**
   369
   370If you need to rollback a pipeline change:
   371
   372.. code-block:: bash
   373
   374   # Revert the code change
   375   git revert <commit-hash>
   376   
   377   # Synthesize and deploy the reverted version
   378   cdk synth
   379   cdk deploy
   380   
   381   # Verify the pipeline is restored
   382   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline
   383
   384Related documentation
   385====================
   386
   387* :doc:`nativedg:create-cdk-pipeline` - Creating CDK-based pipelines
   388* :doc:`golden-path-iac` - Infrastructure as Code best practices
   389* :wiki:`Pipelines/PipelineUpdate` - Internal wiki documentation
   390* :awsdocs:`CDK Pipelines <cdk/v2/guide/cdk_pipeline.html>` - AWS CDK Pipelines guide
   391* :doc:`changeguardian:index` - Change Guardian for risk analysis
   392
   393Support
   394=======
   395
   396For assistance with PipelineUpdate Target:
   397
   398* **Slack**: #pipelines-support channel
   399* **Wiki**: :wiki:`Pipelines/PipelineUpdate/Troubleshooting`
   400* **Tickets**: Create a ticket with the Pipelines team
   401* **Office Hours**: Wednesdays 2-3 PM PT
   402
   403.. include:: includes/reviewers.txt

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
.. Copyright  2025, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

##################################################
Golden Path - PipelineUpdate Target for Pipelines
##################################################

.. meta::
   :description: Golden Path - PipelineUpdate Target for managing pipelines as code

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendations
===============

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_target:

Use PipelineUpdate Target for pipeline self-mutation
----------------------------------------------------

PipelineUpdate Target is a specialized pipeline target that enables automatic pipeline updates using
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) principles. It allows your pipeline to update itself by downloading
build artifacts, parsing the pipeline structure file, and applying changes during deployments.

Unlike CloudFormation-based self-mutation, PipelineUpdate Target provides:

* **Enhanced security**: Uses proper permission boundaries through Bindles
* **Better customer experience**: More reliable and predictable updates
* **Cleaner separation**: Operates as a regular pipeline target with special capabilities
* **Audit trail**: Clear visibility into pipeline changes through standard deployment mechanisms

When you deploy changes through a PipelineUpdate Target, it automatically:

#. Downloads the build artifacts containing your pipeline definition
#. Parses the pipeline structure file (typically generated by CDK)
#. Compares the desired state with the current pipeline configuration
#. Updates the pipeline to match the desired state

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_configuration:

Configure PipelineUpdate Target with CDK
----------------------------------------

To enable PipelineUpdate Target in your CDK application, set the ``createLegacyPipelineStage``
property to ``false`` in your pipeline configuration:

.. code-block:: typescript

   import { DeploymentPipeline } from '@amzn/pipelines';
   
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target mode
     sourceType: 'CodeCommit',
     defaultCodeCommitBranch: 'mainline',
     defaultCodeCommitRepositoryName: 'MyServiceRepo',
     // ... other configuration
   });

This configuration tells the CDK to use Pipeline Target configuration mode instead of the
Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode, enabling the PipelineUpdate Target functionality.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_permissions:

Set up proper permissions through Bindles
-----------------------------------------

PipelineUpdate Target requires appropriate permissions to modify your pipeline. Configure
these permissions through Bindles to maintain security boundaries:

#. Create a Bindle for your pipeline with the necessary permissions:

   * Pipeline read/write permissions
   * Access to the pipeline's artifact bucket
   * Permissions to assume the pipeline's execution role

#. Associate the Bindle with your pipeline target in the CDK:

   .. code-block:: typescript

      import { PipelineUpdateTarget } from '@amzn/pipelines';
      
      const updateTarget = new PipelineUpdateTarget(this, 'UpdateTarget', {
        pipeline: pipeline,
        bindleId: 'amzn1.bindle.resource.your-bindle-id',
        // Additional configuration as needed
      });

#. Ensure your pipeline's execution role has permissions to deploy the PipelineUpdate Target

Best practices
==============

Use version control for all pipeline changes
--------------------------------------------

Since PipelineUpdate Target treats your pipeline as code, all changes should go through
version control:

* Commit pipeline configuration changes to your repository
* Use code reviews to validate pipeline modifications
* Maintain a clear history of pipeline evolution

Implement gradual rollout strategies
------------------------------------

When making significant pipeline changes:

#. Test changes in a development pipeline first
#. Use feature flags or conditional logic to control rollout
#. Monitor pipeline health metrics during and after updates
#. Have a rollback strategy ready

Validate pipeline changes before deployment
-------------------------------------------

Use the Pipelines CLI to preview changes before they're applied:

.. code-block:: bash

   # View the current pipeline configuration
   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline
   
   # Preview what changes will be made
   pipelines pipeline diff --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
     --template-file pipeline-structure.json
   
   # Deploy the changes
   pipelines pipeline deploy --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
     --template-file pipeline-structure.json

Monitor pipeline update deployments
-----------------------------------

Track the success of your pipeline updates:

* Set up CloudWatch alarms for pipeline update failures
* Monitor deployment duration metrics
* Review CloudWatch Logs for detailed update information
* Use pipeline notifications to alert on update status

Caveats
=======

Limitations of PipelineUpdate Target
------------------------------------

While PipelineUpdate Target can modify most pipeline elements, certain properties cannot
be changed:

* **Pipeline name**: The pipeline identifier must remain constant
* **Pipeline description**: The top-level description is immutable
* **Notification email**: The primary notification email cannot be modified

If you need to change these properties, you must create a new pipeline.

Migration considerations
-----------------------

When migrating from Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode to PipelineUpdate Target:

#. Existing pipeline history and artifacts are preserved
#. The migration is one-way; you cannot revert to Legacy Edit mode
#. Ensure all team members understand the new deployment process
#. Update any automation or scripts that interact with the pipeline

Deployment timing
----------------

PipelineUpdate Target updates occur during the deployment phase:

* Changes are applied when the target is deployed, not immediately on commit
* Pipeline updates may cause temporary disruption to in-flight deployments
* Consider scheduling major updates during maintenance windows

Permission boundaries
--------------------

PipelineUpdate Target operates within strict permission boundaries:

* Cannot modify resources outside the pipeline scope
* Cannot change cross-account permissions without proper authorization
* Must respect organizational policies and compliance requirements

When to use
===========

Recommended scenarios
--------------------

Use PipelineUpdate Target when:

* **Managing complex pipelines**: Multiple stages, environments, and approval workflows
* **Frequent pipeline updates**: Regular additions of new stages or deployment targets
* **Team collaboration**: Multiple developers need to modify pipeline configuration
* **Compliance requirements**: Need audit trail and version control for pipeline changes
* **GitOps workflows**: Desire to manage all infrastructure through code

Alternative approaches
---------------------

Consider alternatives when:

* **Simple, static pipelines**: Pipeline rarely changes after initial setup
* **Emergency fixes**: Need immediate pipeline modifications (use console with caution)
* **Learning phase**: Team is new to IaC concepts (start with console, migrate later)

Migration guide
===============

Step 1: Assess current pipeline configuration
---------------------------------------------

Before migration, document your current pipeline:

.. code-block:: bash

   # Export current pipeline configuration
   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
     --output json > current-pipeline.json
   
   # Review CloudFormation stacks if using Legacy Edit mode
   aws cloudformation describe-stacks \
     --stack-name my-service-pipeline-stack

Step 2: Update CDK configuration
--------------------------------

Modify your CDK application to use PipelineUpdate Target:

.. code-block:: typescript

   // Before (Legacy Edit mode)
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     // createLegacyPipelineStage: true (default)
     // ... other configuration
   });
   
   // After (PipelineUpdate Target mode)
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target
     // ... other configuration
   });

Step 3: Configure Bindles and permissions
-----------------------------------------

#. Create or update Bindles for pipeline permissions:

   * Navigate to the Bindles console
   * Create a new Bindle or update existing one
   * Add necessary pipeline update permissions
   * Associate with your pipeline target

#. Update IAM roles if needed:

   .. code-block:: typescript

      const pipelineRole = new iam.Role(this, 'PipelineRole', {
        assumedBy: new iam.ServicePrincipal('pipelines.amazonaws.com'),
        inlinePolicies: {
          PipelineUpdatePolicy: new iam.PolicyDocument({
            statements: [
              new iam.PolicyStatement({
                actions: ['pipelines:UpdatePipeline'],
                resources: ['*'],
                conditions: {
                  StringEquals: {
                    'pipelines:PipelineName': pipeline.pipelineName,
                  },
                },
              }),
            ],
          }),
        },
      });

Step 4: Test the migration
--------------------------

#. Deploy to a test environment first:

   .. code-block:: bash

      # Synthesize the CDK application
      cdk synth
      
      # Review the generated pipeline structure
      cat cdk.out/pipeline-structure.json
      
      # Deploy to test environment
      cdk deploy --context environment=test

#. Verify pipeline functionality:

   * Trigger a test deployment
   * Verify all stages execute correctly
   * Confirm PipelineUpdate Target is working
   * Check CloudWatch Logs for any issues

Step 5: Production rollout
--------------------------

#. Schedule the migration during a maintenance window
#. Communicate changes to your team
#. Deploy to production:

   .. code-block:: bash

      # Final review of changes
      pipelines pipeline diff --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline \
        --template-file cdk.out/pipeline-structure.json
      
      # Deploy to production
      cdk deploy --context environment=prod

#. Monitor the migration:

   * Watch CloudWatch metrics
   * Review deployment logs
   * Verify pipeline updates are working
   * Test a sample deployment

Step 6: Post-migration validation
---------------------------------

After migration, ensure everything is working:

#. **Test pipeline updates**: Make a small change and verify it deploys correctly
#. **Validate permissions**: Ensure all team members can still interact with the pipeline
#. **Update documentation**: Document the new process for your team
#. **Train team members**: Ensure everyone understands the new workflow

Troubleshooting
==============

Common issues and solutions
---------------------------

**Pipeline update fails with permission errors**

* Verify Bindle configuration includes all necessary permissions
* Check IAM role trust relationships
* Ensure artifact bucket permissions are correctly configured

**Changes not appearing after deployment**

* Confirm ``createLegacyPipelineStage: false`` is set in CDK
* Verify CDK synthesis is generating the correct pipeline structure
* Check PipelineUpdate Target deployment logs in CloudWatch

**Deployment takes longer than expected**

* Pipeline updates add overhead to deployment time
* Consider batching multiple changes together
* Review CloudWatch metrics for bottlenecks

**Rollback procedures**

If you need to rollback a pipeline change:

.. code-block:: bash

   # Revert the code change
   git revert <commit-hash>
   
   # Synthesize and deploy the reverted version
   cdk synth
   cdk deploy
   
   # Verify the pipeline is restored
   pipelines pipeline view --pipeline-name my-service-pipeline

Related documentation
====================

* :doc:`nativedg:create-cdk-pipeline` - Creating CDK-based pipelines
* :doc:`golden-path-iac` - Infrastructure as Code best practices
* :wiki:`Pipelines/PipelineUpdate` - Internal wiki documentation
* :awsdocs:`CDK Pipelines <cdk/v2/guide/cdk_pipeline.html>` - AWS CDK Pipelines guide
* :doc:`changeguardian:index` - Change Guardian for risk analysis

Support
=======

For assistance with PipelineUpdate Target:

* **Slack**: #pipelines-support channel
* **Wiki**: :wiki:`Pipelines/PipelineUpdate/Troubleshooting`
* **Tickets**: Create a ticket with the Pipelines team
* **Office Hours**: Wednesdays 2-3 PM PT

.. include:: includes/reviewers.txt

Recommendation
==============

.. _golden-path-pipelineupdate-target:

Use PipelineUpdate Target for self-mutating pipelines
------------------------------------------------------

You should use PipelineUpdate Target as your primary mechanism for managing pipeline 
configurations through code. This approach provides better security, reliability, and 
developer experience compared to CloudFormation-based self-mutation.

**Key benefits**:

* **Infrastructure as Code**: Manage your entire pipeline configuration in your CDK package
* **Version control**: Track all pipeline changes through your standard Git workflow
* **Automated updates**: Pipeline automatically updates itself when you merge changes
* **Security**: Granular permissions through Bindles instead of broad AWS account access
* **Consistency**: Ensures pipeline configuration matches your code at all times
* **Auditability**: Complete audit trail of pipeline changes through Structure History
* **Rollback capability**: Revert to previous pipeline configurations if needed

Technical architecture
----------------------

PipelineUpdate Target operates as a specialized pipeline target that transforms your 
pipeline based on a pipeline structure file generated during the build process:

1. **Build phase**: Your CDK package generates a ``Pipeline.json`` structure file
2. **Deployment phase**: PipelineUpdate Target downloads and parses this file
3. **Mutation phase**: Pipeline service updates the pipeline configuration
4. **Validation phase**: Changes are validated and applied atomically

The pipeline structure file contains:

.. code-block:: json

    {
      "version": "1.0",
      "pipeline": {
        "name": "MyServicePipeline",
        "stages": [...],
        "promotions": [...],
        "approvalWorkflows": [...],
        "deploymentGroups": [...]
      }
    }

**Architecture advantages over CloudFormation**:

.. table:: Comparison of approaches
   :widths: 30 35 35

   ================================ ======================================= =======================================
   Aspect                           PipelineUpdate Target                   CloudFormation (Legacy)
   ================================ ======================================= =======================================
   Permission model                 Pipeline as actor (granular)            AWS Account as actor (broad)
   Update mechanism                 Direct API calls                       CloudFormation stack updates
   Rollback capability              Native support via Structure History   Complex stack rollback
   Manual changes                   Preserved until next deployment        Overwritten on any stack update
   Debugging                        Clear error messages                   CloudFormation event inspection
   Performance                      Fast, direct updates                   Slower stack convergence
   Cross-region support             Native multi-region                    Requires StackSets
   ================================ ======================================= =======================================

file.content:
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) principles. It allows your pipeline to update itself by downloading
build artifacts, parsing the pipeline structure file, and applying changes during deployments.

Unlike CloudFormation-based self-mutation, PipelineUpdate Target provides:

* **Enhanced security**: Uses proper permission boundaries through Bindles
* **Better customer experience**: More reliable and predictable updates
* **Cleaner separation**: Operates as a regular pipeline target with special capabilities
* **Audit trail**: Clear visibility into pipeline changes through standard deployment mechanisms

When you deploy changes through a PipelineUpdate Target, it automatically:

#. Downloads the build artifacts containing your pipeline definition
#. Parses the pipeline structure file (typically generated by CDK)
#. Compares the desired state with the current pipeline configuration
#. Updates the pipeline to match the desired state

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_configuration:

Configure PipelineUpdate Target with CDK
----------------------------------------

To enable PipelineUpdate Target in your CDK application, set the ``createLegacyPipelineStage``
property to ``false`` in your pipeline configuration:

.. code-block:: typescript

   import { DeploymentPipeline } from '@amzn/pipelines';
   
   const pipeline = new DeploymentPipeline(this, 'MyPipeline', {
     pipelineName: 'my-service-pipeline',
     createLegacyPipelineStage: false,  // Enable PipelineUpdate Target mode
     sourceType: 'CodeCommit',
     defaultCodeCommitBranch: 'mainline',
     defaultCodeCommitRepositoryName: 'MyServiceRepo',
     // ... other configuration
   });

This configuration tells the CDK to use Pipeline Target configuration mode instead of the
Legacy Edit (CloudFormation) mode, enabling the PipelineUpdate Target functionality.

.. _golden_path_recommendation_pipelineupdate_permissions:

Set up proper permissions through Bindles
-----------------------------------------

PipelineUpdate Target requires appropriate permissions to modify your pipeline. Configure
these permissions through Bindles to maintain security boundaries:

#. Create a Bindle for your pipeline with the necessary permissions:

edits.old_string:
When you deploy changes through a PipelineUpdate Target, it automatically:

#. Downloads the build artifacts containing your pipeline definition
#. Parses the pipeline structure file (typically generated by CDK)
#. Compares the desired state with the current pipeline configuration

edits.new_string:
When you deploy changes through a PipelineUpdate Target, it automatically:

#. Downloads the build artifacts containing your pipeline definition
#. Parses the pipeline structure file (typically generated by CDK)
#. Compares the desired state with the current pipeline configuration
#. Updates the pipeline to match the desired state
#. Validates the changes against security policies
#. Applies changes atomically (all or nothing)

**Technical Architecture Deep Dive**:

The PipelineUpdate Target operates through several components:

* **Pipeline Structure File**: A JSON specification generated during build that describes your entire pipeline
* **PipelineUpdate Stage**: A special stage inserted after your Version Set stage
* **Deployment Agent**: Orchestrates the update process and handles error recovery
* **Permission Validator**: Ensures the pipeline has necessary permissions for requested changes

The pipeline structure file schema includes:

.. code-block:: json

   {
     "version": "1.0",
     "pipeline": {
       "name": "MyServicePipeline",
       "id": 12345678,
       "stages": [
         {
           "name": "VersionSet",
           "type": "VERSION_SET",
           "versionSetId": "MyServiceVersionSet/mainline"
         },
         {
           "name": "PipelineUpdate",
           "type": "PIPELINE_UPDATE",
           "configuration": {
             "packageName": "MyServiceCDK",
             "structureFile": "Pipeline.json"
           }
         },
         {
           "name": "Packaging",
           "type": "PACKAGING"
         }
       ],
       "promotions": [
         {
           "source": "VersionSet",
           "destination": "PipelineUpdate",
           "automatic": true
         }
       ],
       "approvalWorkflows": [
         {
           "name": "SecurityScan",
           "stage": "Packaging"
         }
       ]
     }
   }

**Comparison with CloudFormation approach**:

.. table:: Architectural differences
   :widths: 25 35 40

   ========================== ============================================= =============================================
   Component                  PipelineUpdate Target                         CloudFormation (Legacy)
   ========================== ============================================= =============================================
   Update mechanism           Direct API calls to Pipelines service        CloudFormation stack convergence
   Permission model           Pipeline actor with scoped Bindle permissions AWS account with broad IAM policies
   Error handling             Granular error messages with context         Generic CloudFormation errors
   Rollback                   Instant via Structure History                Complex stack rollback procedures
   Update speed               ~30 seconds for large pipelines              2-5 minutes depending on stack size
   Manual changes             Preserved between auto-updates               Overwritten on any deployment
   Cross-region               Native support                               Requires StackSets configuration
   Debugging                  Pipeline CLI with detailed output            CloudFormation events and logs
   ========================== ============================================= =============================================

Configure PipelineUpdate Target with CDK
----------------------------------------

To enable PipelineUpdate Target in your CDK application, set the ``createLegacyPipelineStage``
property to ``false`` in your pipeline configuration:

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **
